item.title: Macau Lawyers Association declares support for the State Security Defense Commission law
item.description: The Macau Lawyers Association, chaired by former deputy Vong Hin Fai, considers the requirements required by the proposed law that will regulate the State Security Defense Commission to be reasonable and necessary. In an opinion article signed by the association, published in the newspaper Ou Mun, the veto on the participation of lawyers in any process considered in any way related to national security is defended. In the text, the association argues that many countries and regions have similar laws, pointing to the examples of the Special Advocate Statute in the United Kingdom and Canada, the classified information procedures law in the United States of America and the regulation of legal practitioners in Hong Kong. All the regimes mentioned by AAM are based on legal systems of the Common Law style, the British tradition, which contrasts with the reality of Macau, which adopts a legal system of the so-called continental tradition, with roots in Germany and France and which also applies to Portugal. Full support The association also said that it agrees and supports the proposed law, as it considers that it advances and improves the commission's duties and competencies while “fully applying the general perspective of national security”. The association also cites the justification note to emphasize that “the defense of State security constitutes a constitutional responsibility of the Macao SAR”. The Macau Lawyers Association also highlighted that Macau must “implement the decisions and instructions of the Central Government within the scope of national security” and that this proposed law, by strengthening the powers of the commission, will maintain “coherence with the norms of the Hong Kong national security law” and “coordinate with the Electoral Law for the Chief Executive and the Electoral Law for the Legislative Assembly”.

item.title: Security | Macao SAR rulers applaud White Paper on Hong Kong
item.description: China has released a new White Paper on national security, on Hong Kong, which is entitled “Practice of Safeguarding National Security in Hong Kong under ‘One Country, Two Systems.’ In the Macao SAR, secretaries and political leaders reacted positively, saying that the document provides guarantees of stability and is a reference for Macau Days after the conviction in Hong Kong of Jimmy Lai, a media entrepreneur who founded the now-defunct Apple Daily newspaper, China launches a new White Paper focused on the need to safeguard national security in neighboring territory. The “Practice of Safeguarding National Security in Hong Kong under ‘One Country, Two Systems'” was published by the Communication Department of China's State Council on Tuesday. According to the Xinhua news agency, this White Paper consists of five parts, detailing “the persistent struggle to safeguard national security in Hong Kong and the fundamental responsibility of the Central Government in national security matters related to Hong Kong”. In the same note, it is explained that the White Paper “exposes the achievements of the HKSAR in fulfilling its constitutional responsibility to safeguard national security” and also “Hong Kong’s transition from chaos to stability and prosperity”. “Efforts to create [a security landscape] of high standard are not forgotten in order to promote the high-quality development of the ‘One Country, Two Systems' policy”, in addition to being explained that “the Central Government applied a holistic approach to national security”. In this context, “it effectively exercised general jurisdiction over the HKSAR, in accordance with the country's Constitution and the Basic Law of the HKSAR”, and the Law on Safeguarding National Security “has been applied in the region” and has ensured “that Hong Kong is administered by patriots”. On the Macao SAR side, the government apparatus reacted positively to this White Paper, after the bill that presents a new format and composition of the Macao SAR State Security Defense Commission, created in 2018, was generally approved in the Legislative Assembly. Chan Tsz King, Secretary for Security, was one of the political figures who reacted to the document, which considers “ensuring the stable and lasting implementation” of the “One Country, Two Systems” principle. Quoted in an official note, the secretary understands that the White Paper comes to “clarify the intrinsic unity between political principles and institutional logic, causing Hong Kong society to return to normality and order to be restored”. The document, in the secretary's view, “serves as an important reference for the Macao SAR to review and improve the construction of its legal system in the context of defending the security of the State and the respective execution mechanism”. Chan Tsz King highlights that his leadership will give “great importance to ensuring security in non-traditional areas under the new situation, establishing the long-term stability of the Macao SAR as a strategic objective”. Firm as a rock Also according to Xinhua, the White Paper describes how Beijing “supports the HKSAR in fulfilling its constitutional responsibility to safeguard national security by effectively preventing, interrupting and punishing any activities that put national security at risk”. “The efforts” of the neighboring region to safeguard national security aim, according to the same document, to “sustain and develop” the principle created by Beijing to support Taiwan and the two special administrative regions, without forgetting the protection of “fundamental human rights, dignity and well-being of the 7.5 million residents of Hong Kong”. The White Paper released by the State Council also states that “in today's world, and with unprecedented global transformations that have occurred in a century, they are accelerating, with the development environment facing China undergoing profound and complex changes”. In this way, “safeguarding national security is a long-term and permanent task”, it is said. The White Paper states that Hong Kong “enjoys a high standard of security”, with the region “fated to overcome all risks and challenges in the future journey, remaining as stable as a rock in a turbulent world”. Another political figure from the Macao SAR who reacted was Adriano Marques Ho, director-general of the Customs Service, saying that the White Paper “has an important guiding significance and a profound impact for the complete and accurate implementation of ‘One Country, Two Systems’ in the Hong Kong and Macau regions, for the realization of long-term prosperity and stability, and for their stable and sustainable progression”. Adriano Marques Ho added that “both Hong Kong and Macau are inalienable and sacred parts of China”, and Beijing “has firmly and consistently maintained national sovereignty, security and development interests”. In the view of the top Customs official, “the external hostile forces and anti-China elements disturbing Hong Kong incited and created the ‘legislative review riots’, which ended up evolving into a ‘color revolution’ version of Hong Kong, seriously damaging the constitutional order and the rule of law in Hong Kong, and putting national sovereignty, security and development interests at risk”. End of the “chaotic situation” Lam, Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, said the White Paper “comprehensively analyzes and outlines Hong Kong's journey in defending national security, major achievements and experience gained”. In the governor's view, “Hong Kong went from a chaotic situation to stability and prosperity”. In the case of Macau, the principles contained in the White Paper apply, with the secretary promising to “continue to intensify education, giving priority to the formation of a social base that supports the values ​​of love for the country and for Macau”. In this context, the aim is to “develop a comprehensive educational system to increase the patriotic feeling of young people and consolidate the ideological foundation of national security through multidimensional educational activities and exchanges”. It is promised that the Social Affairs and Culture department “will continue to promote national security using culture as a driving force, reinforcing the exploration and dissemination of Macau’s historical and cultural resources and organizing different types of exhibitions and cultural shows with unique characteristics”. The idea is to “spread the excellent Chinese cultural heritage in order to resist the erosion of harmful cultures, reinforce the cultural and national identity of the population and unite the forces of different sectors of society through culture”. Wong Sio Chak, Secretary for Administration and Justice, who for years held the Security portfolio, considers that the White Paper has “extreme relevance for Macao SAR issues relating to the defense of national security”, particularly with regard to “defending sovereignty, security and the development interests of the State”. The promises are that the area of ​​Administration and Justice “will boost legislative production in the priority areas related to the defense of State security, continuing to improve the respective legal regime”, with “training courses on the Constitution, the Basic Law and legislation relating to the defense of State security aimed at public service workers at different levels”. In turn, Tai Kin Ip, Secretary for Economy and Finance, described that “economic and financial security constitute non-traditional key domains among the twenty priority areas of the global vision of national security, and are also crucial factors in ensuring the stable development and long-term security of Macau and the country”. Tai Kin Ip aims to “pragmatically promote the development of adequate diversification of the economy, strengthening Macau’s global economic resilience and maintaining a high level of attention to various risks and challenges in the economic and financial domain”. Raymond Tam, Secretary for Transport and Public Works, said Macau must “cultivate an awareness of vigilance in times of peace, in order to consolidate the foundations of lasting stability and security”. In this sense, the government official understands that “Macau must always put the safeguarding of the sovereignty, security and development interests of the State first”, and in terms of Transport and Public Works he promises to “persist in the predominance of Executive power, firmly integrating the safeguarding of national security in all tasks”. Ao Ieong Seong, Commissioner against Corruption, believes that “the security and stability of the political environment and the good functioning of the system, with the predominance of the Executive branch, [guarantees that] the level of governance in the Macao SAR is increasingly higher”. The commissioner highlighted “last year’s successful holding of the elections for the 8th Legislative Assembly, reinforcing the implementation of the principle of ‘Macau governed by patriots’ and effectively ensuring the lasting stability of the Macao SAR”.

item.title: Security Committee | Jurists warn of contradiction to the Basic Law
item.description: Despite support for national security issues, the requirements of the State Security Defense Commission's proposed law are considered contrary and incomprehensible in light of Macau's legal framework Analysts interviewed by Lusa consider the proposed law for the Commission for the Defense of State Security, voted yesterday in the Legislative Assembly, to be unconstitutional, highlighting “disturbing aspects”, such as restrictions on the appointment of lawyers in national security cases. The proposed law that will frame the State Security Defense Commission (CDSE) was discussed and voted on in general by deputies to the Legislative Assembly yesterday. The document, according to Macau-based lawyer Luís Almeida Pinto, “contains disturbing aspects of the constitutional functioning of various powers, and also in some matters of rights, freedoms and guarantees enshrined in the Macau ‘Constitution’: the Basic Law”. Anticipating changes to the Basic Law of the Judicial Organization, the proposal determines that the choice of a lawyer for national security cases is subject to the approval of a judge, who forwards the request to the CDSE, so that it can issue a binding and non-appealable opinion. Special authorization, the Government proposes, can occur in criminal or other proceedings, when “there are well-founded reasons to believe that there is a need to protect the interests of State security”. Almeida Pinto evokes the Basic Law, which guarantees “access to the Law, the courts, and assistance from a lawyer in the defense of their legitimate rights and interests”, to point out that it is up to the defendant “to freely choose the lawyer who best serves them”. “It seems like a rule that will be unconstitutional when approved, and when applied in practice”, he explains. Collision with Lawyer's Statute In addition to being “a violation of the Basic Law”, with constitutional force in Macau, Pedro Leal, who has practiced law in the territory for several decades, points out “clearly, a collision” between what is proposed and “the decree that regulates the Lawyers Association and the Statute” of the Lawyer, with regard to the free choice of a defender. This is the “most debatable issue” of the proposal, assumes Leal, who says he agrees with the legislative initiative. "China pays special attention to security issues, it is a world power, as such it does not want interference in any way. I understand the position and I understand that it does not want changes to the 'status quo'. (…) Now, they want to do things, do them well", he adds. Speaking to Lusa, Almeida Pinto also considers the regime envisaged to be “unacceptable” for “inquiries to be made to lawyers” who wish to legally represent a defendant in national security cases. Attached to the request made by the agents to the judge, there must be, among other elements, information regarding the members of the lawyer's household, nationality and connection with organizations or individuals abroad. This is a “real investigation into personal life”, when “what is only at stake is the exercise of the profession for which he is duly registered and authorized by the Macau Lawyers Association”, he says. The requirement, “in addition to being extremely vague, is perfectly impossible” to implement, assesses Leal, who suggests “it is implicit” that a non-Chinese lawyer will not be authorized representation in these cases – it should be noted that in cases of national security, only the intervention of Chinese judges is now permitted. Question of times Another doubt, raised to Lusa by jurist António Katchi, concerns the time it will take for the CDSE to issue the opinion. The proposal does not clarify this aspect, so the Code of Administrative Procedure “should” be applied, which sets the deadline for acts to be carried out by administrative bodies at 15 days. But, says Katchi, “will the CDSE follow this same understanding or will it consider (without the possibility of this being denied by any court) that it can simply leave the issue to its next semi-annual ordinary meeting?”. If the opinion is negative and it is necessary to repeat the process, with a new legal representative, “how many months or years will the defendant remain deprived of his liberty, without a lawyer”? Alluding to the principle of judicial independence, which he recalls is guaranteed by the Basic Law, António Katchi deduces “with complete certainty, the inadmissibility of subjecting a judicial decision to a binding opinion from an administrative body, namely the CDSE”. The professor also talks about the importance of a relationship of trust between constituent and lawyer and “how vital it is, for a person at risk of a prison sentence, to be defended by a lawyer who is sincerely motivated by the cause and well versed in the matter involved”. In addition to the Basic Law and the Joint Declaration, signed by Lisbon and Beijing in 1987, and which defined rules for Macau after the transition of administration, Katchi highlights another legal provision that the proposal contradicts: the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), according to which, he quotes, “every person accused of a crime shall have the right, in full equality, (…) to present himself at trial and to defend himself in person or to be assisted by a defender of your choice.” The ICCPR is one of the instruments that constitute the UN International Bill of Human Rights. In 1992, when Macau was still a territory administered by Portugal, Lisbon extended this convention to the region. Although China signed the treaty in 1998, it never ratified it, and is not bound by its rules. The Basic Law, explains António Katchi, points out that restrictions on fundamental rights, including the right to be assisted by a lawyer, “cannot contradict the provisions of the ICCPR”.

item.title: Diaspora | Greater connection between Casa de Macau and Casa de Goa defended
item.description: The conference “Casa de Goa and Casa de Macau: fundamental agents of an indispensable dialogue” took place in Lisbon yesterday, which analyzed the connecting role that the entities can have in the Goan and Macau diaspora. Carlos Piteira, president of Casa de Macau, highlights the importance of creating bridges with Casa de Goa through the “parallel representation of Portuguese descendants” What role can Casa de Macau and Casa de Goa, in Lisbon, have, taking into account the passage of time and the developments brought by the new generations of the Macanese and Goan communities? It is true that Macau and Goa have long ceased to be part of the former Portuguese empire, but sociocultural ties remain. With this in mind, the lecture “Casa de Goa and Casa de Macau: fundamental agents of an indispensable dialogue” took place yesterday at the Lisbon Geography Society, which sought to outline answers to the challenges of the future. To HM, Carlos Piteira, president of the Casa de Macau in Lisbon, declared that “it would be interesting if the bridges between the Casa de Macau and the Casa de Goa could also be considered in parallel with their representation of Portuguese descendants and mixed cultures”, taking into account that the two entities “are fundamental pillars for the representation of these communities”. The person responsible, himself Macanese, highlights “the similarities of their gastronomy, Creole and festivities” between the two communities. It would therefore be “interesting to combine the small representations of the giants of the Asian world, represented by the symbolism of the Dragon and the Elephant, as structuring elements for a dialogue between Portugal and Asia, political and institutional wills permit”. In Carlos Piteira's view, the two houses “reinforce the legitimized heritage of the dialogue between the West and the East, and Portugal's centuries-old relations with these countries, often ignored and forgotten by official and institutional powers”. Pedro Colaço, from the management of Casa de Goa, highlights the importance of preserving the memory of the Portuguese presence both in Goa and in the remaining territories of Daman and Diu. "There have been 450 years of history, in the case of Macau it was a few more decades, and we try to keep up with current Goan culture. One of the most important parts of our work is to build a bridge between Goa and Lisbon, and on a daily basis we contact artists, musicians and members of the community, that is our role", he described to HM. Pedro Colaço gave the example of the concert that will take place on March 8th at Fundação Oriente, in Lisbon, entitled “Oscar Castellino – Voz de Ópera de Goa and Piano with Rodrigo Ayala”. Furthermore, Casa de Goa, currently without its own headquarters, seeks, like Casa de Macau, to attract new members, especially from the new generations, in order to continue the project, so that the Casa remains “as a hub of unity for Goans and, increasingly, for friends of Goa”. Follow the story Casa de Macau was founded in Lisbon in 1966 and has followed different phases not only in the history of Portugal but also in the country's relationship with Macau and China. "The existence of the House of Macau undoubtedly marks a parallel with the history of Portugal itself for more than 70 years. Macau was the 'pearl of the East' for the Estado Novo and lived through the turmoil of the revolutionary period of April 1974, adapting and establishing itself as the 'bridge between the West and East'". Finally, after the transition to the People's Republic of China, we have seen the reorganization [of Macau] as a central territory in the connection, from China, with Portuguese-speaking countries.” Carlos Piteira also described that the House of Macau has followed “the history of the times, expanding the vision of the Portuguese presence in this territory”. Furthermore, he had a “no less important” task, having “crystallized, protected and perpetuated the Macanese community in Portugal and the world”. Currently, Casa de Macau has developed several activities that bring more members to Avenida Gago Coutinho, where it is located, and whose building has recently undergone restoration work. Every Wednesday there are Macanese food lunches with Chef Tina, originally from Macau, as well as film sessions and lectures. The Casa's mission is currently “to carry out activities to promote Macau and Macanese culture”, providing “support and promotion of studies and works of scientific content about Macau, Macau people” and also providing “institutional interconnection with other entities linked to Macau, Portugal and Casas de Macau in the diaspora”. Who is from Goa and who is not Pedro Colaço explained that the Goan community in Lisbon “has an easier time talking to the remaining Indian diaspora” in Portugal, taking into account that, for example, “the connection is very old” with the Hindu community. “We are sorry that sometimes [the community] is not talked about more in the media, because it is an important part of Portuguese history”, laments the person in charge, remembering prominent figures in the country, such as António Costa, who was Portuguese prime minister, or Narana Coissoró, former president of Casa de Goa and former deputy of the CDS-PP. “There are more notorious figures, but in general the Goan community has integrated itself very well and is known for being a very educated community”, he also recalled, regretting that in Portugal it is not possible to make a distinction between communities of Indian origin. "One thing that is worrying is the lack of knowledge that exists in relation to the communities. Nowadays there is a lot of pressure due to immigration and then everything gets mixed up", highlights Pedro Colaço, remembering that there is a strong feeling in being Goan, particularly in connection with Catholicism and a very unique culture as opposed to Hindustani communities that are currently very present in Portugal. "The Goan community is so mixed that half of my family, or more, do not appear to be Goan, but I, by chance, do. There is a feeling of being Goan, something that unites us. The other communities of the Indian diaspora are often confessional, they have an associated religion, while the Goan community is, for the most part, Catholic, but everyone goes to their own church, it is very spread out", he pointed out. The future is a challenge Pedro Colaço speaks of a “challenging future” for Casa de Goa. "I'm now in my second term, the leadership has changed president, and one of the things we've been trying to do is to bring young people into the governing bodies. We now have three or four younger members, under the age of 40. We've also been trying to expand the House to non-Goans." In this point, there are similarities with the Casa de Macau, which has also sought to expand the range of members to Chinese or Portuguese people who do not belong to the community. Pedro Colaço adds that, over the years, things have changed. "30 years ago the community was very large, but at this moment, and like all institutions, we have to expand. There are many people who really like Goa and who know a lot about the territory, perhaps even more than me, and they are the ones who have to be pulled", he assumed. Currently, Casa de Goa has 500 members and, even without a headquarters, it seeks to carry out activities, particularly in partnership with Fundação Oriente. A monthly bulletin is published. They no longer have headquarters due to the metro works in Lisbon, which has made the House's agenda difficult. “We are in the process of finding a new headquarters, and it is something that has been a constraint, but we try to carry out as many activities as possible and, every month, we always have activities”, concluded Pedro Colaço.

item.title: Cooperation | Relations between China and Timor-Leste guided by caution, study indicates
item.description: It is certain that, by being part of the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, Timor-Leste can become a strategic point in commercial relations on this side of the globe, despite the “cautious pragmatism” in relations with China. A conclusão é de um estudo sobre a política externa timorense no âmbito da iniciativa chinesa, da autoria de três académicos portugueses Timor-Leste, a young country, has been cementing its relations with China, namely through the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, but there is still some caution surrounding this relationship. This is one of the conclusions of the study “Timor-Leste's foreign policy options within the scope of China's Belt and Road 2.0 Initiative: a small state perspective”, authored by academics Tiago Botelho dos Santos, Diogo Borges and Paulo Afonso Duarte. O trabalho foi publicado na The Pacific Review, revista académica editada pela Taylor & Francis. The research work starts with Timor-Leste's adherence to the Chinese initiative, something that happened in 2017, to analyze how the relationship with China has been going, taking into account the fact that Timor-Leste has “the status of a small state”. It is concluded, therefore, that “Timor-Leste's involvement with China's Belt and Road Initiative, particularly in the post-2023 period, can be understood as a strategic and calculated attempt to maximize its status as a small state in a complex regional and global environment”. It is described that, in this period, Timorese foreign policy has been characterized “by a multi-vector approach, strategically anchored in multilateralism”, seeking to “diversify international partnerships to reinforce national security, promote economic development and expand its voice in the international system”. The study points out that relations between Timor-Leste and China, in the context of the Belt and Road initiative, are a “deliberate movement to leverage development opportunities” in the country, being a strategy aligned with the Timor-Leste Strategic Development Plan 2011-2030. The plan aims to “promote economic diversification and the development of critical infrastructure, in a context in which the Belt and Road 2.0 Initiative emphasizes digital infrastructure, green energy and cooperation in the area of ​​health”. Timorese potential The three academics also highlight that Timor-Leste, as part of the Chinese geopolitical initiative, has the potential to stand out economically, and also in commercial terms, in the region. The country has “the potential to assert itself as a logistical center on a route that connects the South Indian Ocean to the South Pacific”, so the Chinese initiative “offers a relevant opportunity to significantly increase its regional prominence and decisively facilitate” integration into ASEAN [Association of Southeast Asian Nations], to which Timor-Leste recently joined. Despite all these positive signs, the study concludes that “although Timor-Leste's relationship with China has deepened, culminating in a comprehensive strategic partnership in 2024, its engagement continues to be marked by cautious pragmatism”. In this context, “the benefits of greater connectivity and investment are carefully weighed against concerns regarding debt sustainability, transparency and possible strategic dependencies”. This caution on the part of Timor-Leste demonstrates its “capacity for action by selectively engaging in projects aligned with its national interests”, navigating the “complexities of competition between great powers in the Indo-Pacific, while maintaining its commitment to a balanced and diversified foreign policy”. Timorese pragmatism is also evident, according to the study, in the fact that the country “not only optimizes development opportunities, but also reinforces its regional position by meticulously analyzing economic benefits in the face of potential risks”. What is strengthened, “ultimately”, is the “capacity for action as a small State”, highlight the authors. A “remarkable” ability The study in question highlights how Timor-Leste has had “a remarkable capacity for action” in the context of the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, using other small States, such as Sri Lanka, as a point of comparison. Citing other studies, the three academics highlight how “Timor-Leste has demonstrated a more cautious approach than countries like Sri Lanka, which have faced significant concerns about debt sustainability associated with BRI [Belt and Road Initiative] projects, or landlocked states like Laos and coastal nations like Cambodia.” In the case of these Southeast Asian countries, “Chinese loans for emblematic projects, such as railways and highways, have drastically increased external debt and dependence on Beijing”. What we sought to do in this investigation was “to examine the unique position of Timor-Leste, not as a financier, but also not as a victim of a ‘debt trap'”, highlighting “the distinct and valuable form of action capacity of a small State within the scope of the BRI”. The authors highlight that, in the last decade, China “significantly expanded its presence in Southeast Asia” through the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, thereby “expanding its regional influence in the economic, security and political spheres”. In this relationship, Timor-Leste has been “far from being a passive observer”, seeking to “actively engage with China to ensure development benefits”. Timor-Leste sought to “identify an opportunity to align with the long-term objectives” of its Strategic Development Plan 2011-2030, analysts indicate. “Strategically, the country also intends to capitalize on its geographic position in emerging commercial maritime routes, particularly through the establishment of a logistics hub in the South Indian Ocean and the South Pacific, potentially reinforcing its regional role as a new integrated member state of ASEAN”, point out the authors. Timor-Leste seeks to “balance economic gains and potential dependencies”, in a geopolitical context that “includes competition between great powers in the Indo-Pacific, where United States policies, under successive administrations, aim to contain China's regional influence”. In methodological terms, the authors carried out this investigation based on reading official reports, documents that serve as the basis for signed bilateral agreements and government documentation. In addition, interviews were carried out with “experts based in both Europe and Asia”. The authors state that they sought to interview academics and diplomats “due to the fact that ordinary citizens are generally unfamiliar with China's global multilateral initiatives, while diplomats tend to be excessively cautious in their statements, as they represent the official position of their state, and not necessarily their personal opinions”. Entende-se, assim, que os académicos “tendem a oferecer análises mais equilibradas e rigorosas”. The questions focused on how Timor-Leste, as a small State, has benefited from the Chinese initiative, whether this initiative is compatible with the Timor-Leste Strategic Development Plan 2011-2030, or whether “there are visible dangers of creating dependency” between the two countries, among other issues.

item.title: USJ | Book highlights panorama of philanthropy in Macau
item.description: The book “Media, Art & Technology in the Nine Portuguese Speaking Cultures” has just been published by the University of São José. Um dos capítulos versa sobre a filantropia em Macau, o perfil discreto dos filantropos e o trabalho de entidades como a Fundação Rui Cunha, Banco Nacional Ultramarino e Fundação Oriente The University of São José (USJ) has just published the book “Media, Art & Technology in the Nine Portuguese Speaking Cultures”, edited by professor José Manuel Simões. As the name indicates, the work aims to outline the panorama of arts, media and culture in the nine Portuguese-speaking countries and regions, which includes Macau. Macao SAR is represented with a chapter dedicated to philanthropy, written by Carmen Zita Monereo, post-doctoral student at USJ, entitled “The Impact of Corporate Philanthropy on Media, Art, and Technology in Macao / What do we know about Philanthropy in Macao? What is the relationship between Confucianism, Philanthropy, Media, and strategic communication?”. “Carmen has been developing a study on philanthropy in Macau, which is a slightly different work than the rest”, she began by telling HM José Manuel Simões. "This is a work that contributes to the analysis of the spectrum of philanthropists in Macau, then outlining a study on the Rui Cunha Foundation, Banco Nacional Ultramarino, Fundação Oriente. It looks at what corporate philanthropy is and the impacts it has on society through an analysis of the media, but also art and technology in Macau. In other words, it questions what we know about philanthropy in Macau and what is the relationship between Confucianism, philanthropy, the media and strategic communication.” José Manuel Simões adds that one of the innovative points in this chapter is the discreet profile of philanthropists. “A curious aspect is that, unlike philanthropists from Europe and the United States, who really like to appear in rankings, in Macau there is greater discretion and a low profile of these people linked to philanthropy, and this has to do with the culture itself.” The editor of the work adds that “in the field of communication sciences [in Macau] philanthropy has gained great importance as a communication instrument”, and that Carmen Zita Monereo’s work “identifies the values ​​of an organizational culture that is capable of generating communication flows conducive to innovation through this philanthropic activity”. The book, which is available for free in digital version, “seeks to draw links between various vectors, and one of them is the nine Portuguese-speaking cultures”, without forgetting Macau “as a connection platform between China and Portuguese-speaking countries”. According to José Manuel Simões, it is a book “whose research was developed seeking to adopt a multidisciplinary approach”, having “an academic nature, but, at the same time, it aims to have a simple and accessible language”. Cape Verde’s good example With a bilingual edition, the book presents “a very broad spectrum” of themes, containing an article by José Manuel Simões on São Tomé and Príncipe, entitled “Digital Media Contribution to Entrepreneurship and Development in São Tomé and Príncipe”. Below is an article on the educational panorama in Angola and the use of artificial intelligence (AI), written by Wilson Gomes Caldeira, entitled “Angola’s higher education system: An analysis of the opportunities and challenges presented by Artificial Intelligence”. In the case of Cape Verde, Silvino Lopes Évora explores the ideas of social communication in conjunction with AI, in “Artificial Intelligence, newsroom culture, and journalism: From international spectrum to experiences in Cape Verde”. “Cape Verde is a good example of media development in Africa and Silvino Évora's text works on the AI ​​component in the media and how it is being inserted. [The text also analyzes] what are the possibilities for using AI and how ethics can monitor and support AI and, at the same time, journalism”, adds José Manuel Simões. The book published by USJ also explores, in the chapter “The media system as a leverage for democratic development in East Timor”, by Paulo Faustino and Rui Alexandre Novais, the links between journalism and the historical memories of the independence process. The book's editor explains the “more historical component regarding the role of remission that journalists still have today to almost preserve the memory of those who died in favor of the country's independence”. "Journalism is of enormous importance in Timor, there were people and journalists who died. This is very little talked about and in this study there is an interesting conclusion, that these people, when they died in the name of freedom of expression, left a very important place in Timor-Leste that is still in force today, seeking to preserve their memory through surveillance over other powers." In this way, “Timor-Leste is almost an example of how journalism should act as a watchdog of other powers, which does not happen in other sectors”. José Manuel Simões highlights the case of Guinea-Bissau, “where journalists are called hired mouths”. "They don't know the difference between advertising, public relations, marketing and journalism, because they are conditioned by a very low salary. They write what they ask for in exchange for an envelope with some money inside, and this makes the profession [of journalism] very fragile in Guinea Bissau", he stressed. A language of unity According to José Manuel Simões, the book aims to unite “these quadrants of Portuguese cultures”, and the English edition aims to reach Anglo-Saxon communities, “so that they know about the existence of these cultures”. "There are those who do not agree with me regarding the idea that the Portuguese language is a language of unity, not only among Portuguese-speaking peoples, but even within each country. We have the case of Timor-Leste, which on the island of Ataúro alone, which is very small, with 500 thousand inhabitants, has 40 dialects, one in each village. There, what does the Portuguese language do? It unites these people, because despite there being a difference between the who speak and those who learned Portuguese, in Timor-Leste, today, the elderly speak Portuguese and young people too, but there is the age group that goes from 25 to 50, who do not speak it. But, because it is a language of learning, because it is official, because it has books, a memory, Portuguese unites all these ethnicities and dialects, and has a common value, because the Portuguese language is everyone's mother tongue”, he explains. José Manuel Simões does not forget the work that CPLP – Community of Portuguese Speaking Countries, has done in this regard. "The CPLP had a wonderful idea of ​​uniting us through language, but the CPLP has done vague, limited and barely visible work. In fact, very few people have done a worthy job of creating links between new Portuguese-speaking cultures. In this sense, this book fills a gap and brings new data about these new cultures, with this technological and innovative dynamic", this in relation to the QR codes for all chapters of the book. Each code gives access to a video that summarizes the author's work in each chapter. In global terms, “Media, Art & Technology in the Nine Portuguese Speaking Cultures” aims to be comprehensive in areas such as technology, art, culture and social communication. There is, however, “a common denominator, creating, curiously, a certain harmony, even with different focuses, and ends up covering, directly and indirectly, the spectrum of social communication”, he concludes.

item.title: Diocese of Macau/450 years | New Catholic Center will have a hotel
item.description: The new Catholic Center should open “in the middle of the second quarter” of this year and will have a hotel, prepared to receive “pilgrims and tourists”, says the Diocese of Macau. At a time when the institution celebrates 450 years, the inauguration of the Catholic Center is based on “the vision” of D. Paulo José Tavares, bishop of Macau in the 60s and 70s After many years of emptiness and construction work on the corner of Avenida da Praia Grande and Rua do Campo, the new Catholic Center is preparing to open its doors later this year and is perhaps the most important event in the celebration of the 450th anniversary of the Diocese of Macau. HM asked questions to the Diocese of Macau regarding the reopening of the building, which confirmed that the official opening is scheduled “for the second quarter” of this year. This building, with a total of 17 floors, will have features designed for religious purposes, but also a hotel prepared to receive all types of people. "The Catholic Center will be a nerve center for disseminating and sharing the mission of the Catholic Church. The lower floors will feature a chapel, an auditorium, conference rooms, exhibition areas and spaces for activities." While “the upper floors will function as a hotel, offering welcoming and comfortable accommodation, imbued with a spirit of service”. In the diocese's written response, it is added that the hotel facilities “were designed to receive both pilgrims and tourists, welcoming Catholics and non-Catholics with hospitality and inclusion”. It is worth remembering that in December employees began to be recruited for the hotel unit, in partnership with the Directorate of Services for Labor Affairs (DSAL). In a job matching session aimed at residents, held on December 5th, with the “Companhia de Gestão do Centro Católico”, 23 job openings were made available for sales manager, assistant reception manager, chef, head of security, room service supervisor and acquisition supervisor, reads the DSAL note released in November. The Diocese of Macau did not want to tell HM how much it would cost to rebuild the new Catholic Center, saying only that initial forecasts had slipped due to the pandemic. "The Catholic Center is currently undergoing development and submission and approval by the Government. Following the challenges of the Covid-19 pandemic, construction costs have increased significantly. We are grateful for the understanding and support of the builders and contractors, which allowed the reconstruction project to be completed successfully. At the same time, we warmly welcome donations from all sectors of society to help sustain and carry forward the Catholic Center's original mission of serving the Macau community." A bishop still present Asked about the main goals of the new Catholic Center, the Diocese of Macau describes that the building “aims to continue the spiritual mission of the Catholic Church and incorporate the spirit of Christ”, influenced by the work of Bishop D. Paulo José Tavares, who carried out his mission in Macau in the mid-20th century. Of particular note is the fact that D. Paulo José Tavares, who died in 1973 and was appointed Bishop of Macau in 1961, was important in maintaining the presence of the Catholic Church in Macau at the time of the “1,2,3” movement. Between November 1966 and February 1967, the Cultural Revolution manifested itself in the territory, bringing together many local students, who intended to change the content of Catholic education. D. Paulo José Tavares fought with these groups of protesters, managing to keep teaching in Catholic schools and the spirit associated with them unchanged. In this way, and based on “the vision” of this bishop, the diocese intends for the new Catholic Center to “continue to serve as a vital bridge for the Macau community, promoting dialogue, exchange and integration of faith and culture”. It is also the intention to “open the doors [of the Center] to visitors from all over the world, reinforcing not only its role as a spiritual refuge, but also infusing new vitality into the religious and cultural panorama of Macau”. António Pedro Costa, author of the cleric's biography, entitled “D. Paulo José Tavares – The diplomat bishop”, described, in an interview with HM in 2023, that the bishop “was a breath of fresh air”, and a figure cherished by the Chinese community at the time. "These attitudes of valuing the Chinese community led to a rapprochement and the establishment of a relationship of trust. Only in this way was he able to take his objectives forward, as he realized that he had to have the population on his side. But this caused him a lot of trouble with the European clergy, who did not agree with D. Paulo José Tavares' stance. It meant that the population saw him as an ally and not a person who comes from outside and imposes his ideas", said the author. A year of celebrations It was in 1576, in the fourth year of the Wanli reign, of the Ming Dynasty, that the Diocese was founded in Macau, with January 23rd being the official date of celebration. However, the next few months will also be festive. In a previously released statement, the Diocese of Macau states that it has had, over the years, “the mission of establishing bridges between East and West, promoting education, charity and pastoral service”, leaving “a deep and lasting mark on the cultural, educational and religious development of Macau”. The theme of the celebrations is “From Macau to the World: 450 years of Mission and Mercy”. The new Catholic Center will host two thematic exhibitions, entitled “Honoring the Past, Creating the Future” and “Witness to Heritage, Mission in the World”. These exhibitions aim to “reflect the development of the Diocese from historical, personal and cultural perspectives, as well as its future directions”, highlights the same note. Tomorrow a sacred music concert will take place at the Sé Church with eight choral groups from Macau, Hong Kong and the Province of Guangzhou, with the sounds of the church's new pipe organ being heard. From 7:30 pm onwards, the Diocesan Choir of Macau, the Cathedral Schola ensemble and other choral groups from Macau will perform, such as Coro Perosi, Dolce Voce and Cantate Chorus, without forgetting other ensembles from Hong Kong and Guangzhou. The Diocese highlights that the “most symbolic and large-scale initiative of the commemorative year” will be the “great celebration” scheduled for October 31st this year, which consists of a reception and mass. “Through this solemn celebration, the Diocese will give thanks to God for the graces and mission granted over four and a half centuries, and will pray that He continues to guide the way forward”, the same statement describes. There will also be initiatives carried out by “various diocesan institutions” in the coming months, namely “cultural shows, school competitions, academic symposiums, social activities, youth meetings, online training resources, parish initiatives and liturgical celebrations”. “Through transversal and intergenerational participation, the commemorative year seeks to deepen public knowledge about the historical development of the Diocese and its service to the community, promoting the spirit of the diocesan motto ‘Scientia et Virtus’ (Science and Virtue), which inspires a practice of service based on the balance between knowledge and ethical care.” At a time when it celebrates 450 years of existence, the Diocese says it wants to chart the future, “walking with the residents of Macau in reflecting on the past and continuing its mission of faith, service and culture in this new stage”.

item.title: Economic Housing | Requested dates for exchange arrangements
item.description: Deputy Nick Lei wants to know when the Government will present the economic housing exchange scheme. The matter appears in a written interpellation presented by the legislator. The affordable housing exchange aims to help households move into apartments that keep up with the growth in membership. The deputy linked to the Fujian community recalled that the Secretary for Transport and Public Works, Raymond Tam, stated that he will develop this regime in accordance with the results that foresee the optimization of housing policy in Macau over the next five years. The study was completed last year. The deputy also wants to know when the Government will implement the permanent application mechanism for economic housing, instead of the competition application model, as this type of housing is sufficient to satisfy current demand. Nick Lei also argues that it is necessary for the Government to review the intermediate housing policy, and asks whether a new study and a new public consultation can be carried out.

item.title: Nipah | Request for more virus prevention
item.description: Representative Leong Hong Sai defended, according to the newspaper Ou Mun, that there should be better prevention against the Nipah virus during the Chinese New Year, which is approaching, even though the virus does not have a significant impact on the territory. The deputy hopes that residents ensure personal protection and hygiene, taking into account that a period is approaching when many people travel, with Leong Hong Sai adding that it is important to reinforce, on the part of the Government, border supervision, without forgetting temperature measurement for suspected cases. The deputy also considers that the Executive must ensure the coordination of hygiene work in community work, reinforcing the frequency of cleaning and disinfection actions in streets with a greater concentration of people. Leong Hong Sai also hopes that authorities will soon complete the Nipah virus emergency response plan.

item.title: Discrimination | DSAL no complaints from women in five years
item.description: Since the beginning of the year, 29 single mothers have been integrated into the world of work under the Professional Reintegration Plan for Women In the last five years, the Directorate of Services for Labor Affairs (DSAL) has not received any complaints from women, motivated by gender discrimination. The information was revealed in response to a question from deputy Ella Lei Cheng I, linked to the Federation of Workers' Associations of Macau (FAOM). According to the response, signed by Hon Wai, president of the Institute of Social Action, the Government “has been attaching importance to safeguarding the rights and interests of women and children in Macau”, which is why the Council for Women and Children's Affairs (CAMC) has drawn up the “Objectives for the Development of Women in Macau”, to define policies in this area, together with 11 public services. Within the scope of these policies, DSAL has been responsible for monitoring discrimination at work, although there have been no complaints in the last five years. “In the last five years, DSAL has not received complaints from workers discriminated against because they are female,” it was revealed. Still, DSAL promises that it is ready to carry out its functions. “DSAL is committed to protecting and defending the legitimate labor rights and interests of workers, being certain that, if it becomes aware that any worker has been treated in a discriminatory and unfair manner, it will monitor and investigate the case in accordance with the law”, it was guaranteed. “If it is found that the act in question involves a criminal crime, the case will be forwarded, in accordance with the law, to the police authorities for monitoring purposes”, it was added. Limits of pregnancy In response to Ella Lei, the president of the IAS also guarantees that the law already provides that a pregnant worker does not perform tasks that could threaten her health. “The ‘Law on Labor Relations’ currently in force already regulates maternity leave and the worker’s guarantees, among other matters, expressly providing that, during pregnancy or in the three months after giving birth, the worker cannot be tasked with performing tasks that are inadvisable for her condition”, it was pointed out. “In addition, DSAL consistently encourages employers who are able to, based on legal requirements, in compliance with the principle of good faith, reach an agreement with workers on working conditions or provide more facilities in the workplace, for example, creating time for breastfeeding or space for expressing breast milk”, it was highlighted. Regarding the promotion of employment for single-parent mothers, the IAS indicates that the “Professional reintegration plan for women”, which lasts six months and began at the beginning of the year, led to 29 mothers being integrated into the world of work.

item.title: TNR | Maternity leave allowance defended
item.description: The Macau Property Management Association hopes that the Government's plan to subsidize the salaries of workers who take maternity leave will include non-resident workers. The position was left by Paulo Tse, president of the association, and justified by the need to avoid rising costs for companies. Speaking to the newspaper Ou Mun, the official explained that the property management sector in Macau essentially covers three categories, namely property management, security and cleaning, employing 28 thousand people, and among these around 85 percent are non-residents, the vast majority, therefore. However, the official pointed out that the maternity leave allowance excludes TNR, and given that the sector depends on these workers, companies will face difficulties due to the increase in human resources costs. Paulo Tse further explained that the sector will also suffer from plans to increase maternity leave and increase the number of holidays, which is currently six days.

item.title: Management of the Lawyers Association admits not having heard members
item.description: The Macau Lawyers Association (AAM) declared that only the management was heard and issued an opinion on the proposed law for the State Security Commission (CDSE), due to the urgency and confidentiality of the consultation. In statements to the public broadcaster Teledifusao de Macau (TDM), released on Wednesday night, the president of the AAM Association indicated that the opinion was issued even before the final proposal. “We supported this preliminary project, taking into account the improvement of the national security defense regime”, declared Vong Hin Fai. The statements come after jurists warned Lusa – even before the general approval of the law that will regulate CDSE, on Tuesday – of the obligation for the Government to consult the AAM about this legislative step. Until that moment, neither the Government nor the association had mentioned any consultation or opinion. When presenting and voting on the law, the Secretary for Security, Chan Tsz King, only mentioned having heard “the legal sector”. The following day, the secretary's office assured Lusa that “the authorities consulted the Macau Lawyers Association in advance, in accordance with the law”, and the latter did not raise “any doubts”. After the silence However, the office did not clarify whether AAM had produced an opinion when asked about it. Now, Vong Hin Fai comes to guarantee that the law was respected and that the AAM was consulted. The opinion was produced exclusively by the management, he stated, “taking into account the timing and confidential nature of this legislative consultation”. “And urgency”, added the general secretary of AAM, Oriana Inácio Pun, also speaking to TDM. Last week, when presenting the new proposal to journalists, the spokesperson for the Executive Council, Wong Sio Chak, mentioned that the diploma was going to the Legislative Assembly for consideration “without urgency”.

item.title: Shuttlebus | Chan Hao Weng criticizes the impact of the law on the lives of residents
item.description: The deputy linked to ATFPM points out that the measure is harming residents of private buildings and also travel agencies, which face drops in revenue Deputy Chan Hao Weng criticized the Government over the law that prevents condominiums from hiring buses from travel agencies to provide transport services for residents, normally referred to as a shuttle bus. The matter was addressed by the legislator linked to the Macau Public Service Workers Association (ATFPM) through a written interpellation. Since the beginning of the month, the new law on the activity of travel agencies and the profession of tourist guide came into force, which meant that residential buildings had to look for alternatives to continue offering the shuttle bus service. At issue is the fact that historically the service has been contracted by condominiums to travel agencies, which the new law prevents. The new policy was approved in June 2025 by the Legislative Assembly, including the votes of Chan's bench colleagues, deputies José Pereira Coutinho and Che Sai Wang. Residential buildings now have the alternative of contracting the service to public transport companies, which, according to Chan Hao Weng's inquiry, has reduced the number of trips. The legislator also indicates that the effect has been most felt in the Jardins do Oceano and One Oasis housing complexes. “Due to staff shortages at these bus companies, the original three daily services to One Oasis were drastically reduced to just one, seriously disrupting residents’ daily commutes,” he pointed out. “What immediate measures will the authorities implement to increase service frequency and urge the bus company to quickly recruit additional staff and restore normal operations?”, he asked. Agencies to suffer The problem is not limited to residential buildings, Chan Hao Weng reveals that travel agencies themselves are suffering a loss of revenue. “At the same time, the abolition of these transport services directly affected the operations of the original travel agencies and the income of the drivers employed”, said the deputy. “With regards to the operational impact on travel agencies and the loss of income for drivers following the crackdown on special buses, what specific support measures and employment safeguards will the authorities implement?”, he was asked. The deputy also wants bus companies to have access to more workers. “Given the high unemployment rate in Macau and the large pool of potential candidates willing to work as bus drivers, how will the authorities help bus concession companies to optimize recruitment processes to quickly fill staff vacancies?”, he asked.

item.title: HZM Border | Concession yields 1.2 million per month
item.description: Sociedade Express Grupo Limitada will pay 1.2 million patacas monthly to the Macao SAR to operate the commercial areas of the Macau Border Post Building on the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge (HZM). The information was published yesterday in the official bulletin, where the contract was announced. The contract has a duration of five years, meaning the final amount paid to the Macao SAR should be around 72 million patacas. The deadline starts from the effective start of exploration, which can happen until May 31st. As part of the contract, the concessionaire commits to ensuring that 30 percent of the commercial space comes into operation, excluding self-service services. Furthermore, the company can change the space to expand commercial areas, but is obliged to maintain good business and hygiene conditions. If the commercial area is increased, the contract also provides for an increase in the monthly rent price, calculated according to the effective increase in space. Sociedade Express Grupo was founded in 1999 in Macau and its main activity is operating pharmacies, linked to the Wan Tung brand, with around 30 spaces in the territory. However, its activities also extend to travel agency services, and the company's portal guarantees that it is the main representative in Macau of Cebu Airlines, although it also has links with other companies such as China Eastern, China Southern, Eva Air, among others.

item.title: You need to know how to govern
item.description: On the day the Minister of Internal Administration took office, we spoke to a commander of the National Republican Guard (GNR) who told us “Oh, my dear, this minister Maria Lúcia Amaral is going to be a disaster... you are a very good jurist, but you don't have the slightest ability to deal with men with wiry beards, nor do you have the slightest idea of ​​what the security forces are and what needs to change in such a disturbed and obscure panorama”. The commander was right. The minister was a black page of the current Government and ended up resigning in times of calamity. He had to resign forcibly. He was already a “jester” within the PSP, GNR and Civil Protection. You left the country astonished when it was only three days after Storm Kristin hit Leiria and Marinha Grande that you came out to say… nothing! Several politicians and television commentators had long called for the Prime Minister to replace the Minister of Internal Affairs. Luís Montenegro turned a deaf ear and the result was the same as the catastrophe that has hit the national territory. Montenegro looked around at his friends and did not immediately find a new minister for such an important portfolio. Montenegro does not have a vision of reality. By the way, Portugal has a personality who should immediately be invited, if he were willing, to occupy the position of Minister of Internal Administration. Only Admiral Gouveia e Melo knows how to coordinate the Armed Forces with the GNR, PSP, Fire Department and Civil Protection. And it was seen in the Covid-19 pandemic. We did not vote for presidential candidate Gouveia e Melo, but we recognize his stance as an organizer, coordinator and with seriousness in taking the position of Minister of Internal Administration in difficult times for the country, which finds itself from North to South in a situation of tragedy. Last week, the unimaginable happened. No one, much less an infrastructure official, ever thought that the country's main highway, the A1 that connects Lisbon to Porto, could collapse due to the rupture of a dike on the Mondego River. In the Coimbra area, motorists will be unable to use the highway for months. We always come back to the same thing: we need to know how to govern. And the Government, at the beginning of the storms that have ravaged the country, was not up to the tragic events. It did not even include the storage of a substantial amount of generators in the planning for a new blackout or other type of catastrophe. It would be the least. More than 20,000 Portuguese people are still without electricity, two weeks after the first storm that knocked down power poles and flooded gas stations. The truth is that thousands of Portuguese people have been displaced from their homes and evacuated from villages surrounded by water. In the Coimbra area, the marines never stop transporting people, food and other goods in their amphibious vehicles for a day. There are people who are left with nothing. A life to build a house and from one day to the next they found themselves completely without what they had gathered for years. The lands in various parts of the country are saturated with water and in the near future, according to experts, these lands will collapse and the houses that are in their path will be destroyed. Even in Porto Brandão, next to Trafaria, and in Costa de Caparica, the cliff collapses left hundreds of people homeless. And for years, the Almada City Council did not foresee that the tragedy could happen? We have many competent mayors in Portugal, but we also have incompetent and corrupt ones who only care about building roundabouts and other megalomaniac works for the Spanish to see. The reconstruction of this calamity that hit Portugal will take years and one of the most important works, the installation of underground electrical lines, has already received the “solidarity” verdict from the European Union: it does not grant support for this. And this is how the Portuguese are witnessing a flooded country, with agriculture destroyed, with houses and factories that have disappeared and with an endless line of trucks that transport much of what feeds the population, due to a highway viaduct that collapsed, and who knows how it was built... we just hope that in the future they will know how to govern with the aim of providing the Portuguese with a better and more peaceful life.

item.title: Camões, the maricón
item.description: He was a Christian, baptized António and was born on the island of Java, hence the gentile name Jau, who gives his name to a street in Lisbon, at the intersection of that of the Lusíadas. Luís Vaz would have met this new friend of his following a shipwreck in Cambodia – perhaps when he passed through the land of “loving Malays, brave Jaus” (X.44.4,7) coming from Macau, where he had never been. Or while waiting for a ship to take him to Cochin and then to Goa, around 1565. Or he actually met him in Goa, the Sodom of the East. From that moment on, António would not let go of him until Luís died. He expired in the arms of his slave. This is the myth, of course. The only historical sources we have are the first Camonian biographers, Pedro Mariz, Severim de Faria and Manuel de Faria e Sousa, who rarely refer to him. Those who are more attentive (and also those who are in the know) realize that what existed between Luís and António was a loving relationship. Not a loving relationship as we would understand it today, but a connection with hierarchies, perhaps fixed places. Camões was much older, a washed-up man in his late forties; Jau was a newly racialized young Christian in Lisbon. It was certainly forbidden for him to walk wherever he wanted. On the street, I should go shopping and little else, or ask for him on the streets of Lisbon, as some say. At home, he acted as a nurse, perhaps a servant, perhaps a lover. In Camões literature, or literature that has recovered this theme, Jau plays several roles: faithful friend, canine, Camões's alter ego, confidant, soulmate or even subliminally a boyfriend, which comes to the surface in some less naive, more knowledgeable texts. After all, the smartest people understand what was encrypted so as not to be understood. In the biographies and literature produced on this topic (which even enchanted Portuguese, German and French romanticism: we have paintings, plays, poems – even operas, on the subject!), he usually accompanies the Poet in the ambiguity of friendship until the end of his life. But a slave friend. Tradition began, however, to identify him as a slave only after a saying by Manuel de Faria e Sousa. A commentator who they call fanciful, but who perhaps knew what he was doing. After all, isn't slavery a metaphor for love, which Camões himself uses? Whoever says Bárbara, says jau. It is an obvious literary metaphor about the chains of affection, a code shared between his closest friends and some later ones who understood the allusions, probably a humanist homosocial circle and their descendants. It has already been suggested that Jau had been bought and rescued in Goa by the Poet, who had gone into debt because of the servant; that this same Jau, who would be an interpreter, was shipwrecked with his master at the mouth of the Mecong and went with him to Mozambique and from there to Lisbon. Poignant legends, but unlikely, says Storck. In fact, António died before the poet, and the latter only managed to survive him for a few months. This is the little information we have. As the German biographer recalls, all slaves had to pay freight to come to the Kingdom and then, in Portugal, entry rights, owed to the King. Who would pay them, if not poor Luís? This shows that he was not a slave at all. Camões did not have the resources to make a blind man sing, let alone own a slave. Storck again: a Jau slave who spoke three languages ​​fluently (his Javanese, plus Chinese and Portuguese) would certainly not be cheap. There were even Jau slaves in Lisbon. There was no need for Luís to bring one from so far away. João de Barros bought one, apparently Chinese. But the historian had a broad purse, and the Poet not so much. Now, this memory also comes with regard to the recent film El cautivo (2025), by Amenábar, which tells how Miguel de Cervantes was captured by privateers and locked up for five years in an Algiers prison. There was some controversy when the film suggested the possible homosexuality of the national author. This issue is not new, and there are disputes in Spanish criticism about his sexuality. Were you accused of sodomy or not? At least here there is a discussion, while in Portugal the suggestions about the same in Camões are light, distant, flying. Fernando Arrabal, author of Un esclavo llamado Cervantes, explained that his biography, published in 1995, is based on a document, dated 1569, according to which Miguel de Cervantes was accused of homosexuality when he was 21 years old and condemned by the King of Spain to the amputation of his right hand and exile. Was that why Cervantes had no use of his arm? And there are Cervantists who in fact speak not only of their homosexuality but also recognize their Jewish origins. The latter also came forward for our Luís, through Fiama's pity. They are metaphors for each other, if we look closely. Things seen as other, prohibited, that must be kept secret, and for which only small, closed groups hold the hermeneutic key. But after all, these are things that are within so many. They are also metaphors for each other: being Jewish is a metaphor for homosexual, and vice versa. In addition to being, or having been, concrete possibilities of life, they are also signs for some life that is behind the sign, the verb or the image, and that we do not achieve. Amenábar takes sides, of course, and does it well, in a beautiful film that transforms Miguel into Scheherazade who, together with her lover, the Bey of Algiers, postpones his death with stories. I think it's an excellent film, as entertainment, even if it's too focused on Cervantes as a storyteller, when Cervantes is far from being just that. Our Spanish brothers, on the other hand, even found the film mild and not very sexualized. In Portugal it would perhaps be a scandal if they did something like that for Camões. Many would think that they wanted to muddy the water. A good film would be one that gave a face to his abandonment, in which only with Jau did he find refreshment. Mário Cláudio, Eugénio de Andrade and Alfredo Margarido were among the few who dared to go there. The point I want to reach is the following: it would not be so much to present a gay Camões, but rather to show how his life and work open up to other landscapes, also sexual, as Frederico Lourenço says in the entry on Love in the Camões Dictionary, by Aguiar e Silva. It's for the next centenary.

item.title: The Dispute over Greenland (II)
item.description: “Nations do not compete for land; they compete for the power that land unlocks.” Halford J. Mackinder The position of the European Union (EU) in the face of the United States' growing attention to Greenland, intensified during Donald Trump's presidency, generated concern and strategic reflection. Although Greenland has not been part of the EU since 1985, the island remains part of the Kingdom of Denmark, a Member State of the Union, which gives the issue an unavoidable political and institutional dimension. The European position thus results from the need to protect the territorial integrity of one of its members, to safeguard strategic interests in the Arctic and to preserve the stability of transatlantic relations. The EU views Greenland as part of the broader European political space, not because of its formal membership, but because of its constitutional connection to Denmark. Any external attempt to acquire or exercise control over territory is interpreted as a direct interference with the sovereignty of a Member State. The American proposal to purchase the island was received in Brussels as a disruptive diplomatic gesture, which went beyond the traditional limits of cooperation between allies. The defense of Danish sovereignty constitutes the first pillar of the European position. The EU has reiterated that the territorial integrity of its Member States is non-negotiable and that any change to the status of a European territory requires full and voluntary consent from national and local authorities. The idea of ​​a territorial transaction, reminiscent of 19th century practices, contradicts contemporary principles of international law and European governance. The EU recognizes the Arctic as a region of growing importance, both for its environmental relevance and its geopolitical value. The accelerated melting of ice, the opening of new maritime routes and access to strategic mineral resources transformed the region into a space for competition between great powers. The EU, which defines itself as a “global actor”, seeks to ensure that the Arctic remains a zone of peaceful cooperation, governed by multilateral norms and shared management mechanisms. American interest in Greenland is interpreted in Brussels as part of a broader strategy of military and economic assertion in the Arctic. Although the United States is a fundamental ally within NATO, the EU maintains reservations about unilateral initiatives that could alter the regional balance. The excessive militarization of Greenland, particularly through the possible installation of nuclear weapons, would be seen as a factor of instability, with a direct impact on European security. Greenland has vast reserves of critical minerals, including rare earths, essential for the energy transition and the European technology industry. The EU has sought to reduce dependence on external suppliers, especially China, and sees cooperation with Greenland as an opportunity to strengthen its strategic autonomy. The American interest in controlling these resources raises concerns in Brussels, which fears an excessive concentration of power over vital supply chains. The EU argues that mining exploration in Greenland must be carried out in a sustainable, transparent manner and in partnership with European actors, guaranteeing benefits for the local population and avoiding predatory exploration practices. The EU deeply values ​​the transatlantic relationship, but considers that strong alliances require mutual respect and predictability. The American proposal to acquire Greenland was interpreted as a gesture that disregarded European political sensitivity and put trust between partners at risk. Brussels sought, however, to avoid a diplomatic escalation. The European response combined firmness in defending Danish sovereignty with discursive moderation, in order to preserve strategic cooperation with Washington in areas such as defense, trade and international security. The EU stressed that dialogue on the Arctic should take place in multilateral forums and within the framework of NATO, and not through unilateral initiatives. Trump's statements at the 2026 Davos Forum further intensified these tensions. Before global leaders, Trump stated that the United States “will not use force” to acquire Greenland, although he stressed that the country would be “frankly unstoppable” if it decided to do so. He added that “no other nation can defend Greenland” and that Washington intended to begin “immediate negotiations” to take control of the territory. In one of the most controversial passages, he declared: "We want a piece of ice to protect the world, and they won't give it. You can say yes and we will be very grateful, or you can say no and we will remember." Trump also reinforced the historical narrative according to which the United States “saved Greenland” during World War II and insinuated that returning the territory to Denmark would have been a mistake. He repeated criticism of NATO, accusing European allies of contributing little to common security, and threatened to impose tariffs of 10% on several European countries, increasing to 25% if the sale of Greenland did not go ahead. European reactions were immediate and firm. Danish Foreign Minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen considered it “positive” that Trump had taken the military option off the table, but stressed that “the president’s ambition remains intact” and that American pressure continued to be unacceptable. In Brussels, the statements were interpreted as a rhetorical escalation that undermined trust between allies and sought to transform Greenland into an instrument of economic and strategic blackmail. European diplomats called the speech “bellicose” and “out of line with the spirit of cooperation” expected at the Davos Forum, noting that the threat of tariffs on EU Member States constituted a form of coercion incompatible with stable transatlantic relations. Denmark, although responsible for Greenland's foreign and defense policy, faces specific challenges in managing the territory. The island's growing autonomy, combined with interest from external powers, places Copenhagen in a delicate position. The EU has sought to support Denmark, strengthening its negotiating capacity and offering instruments for economic and scientific cooperation with Greenland. Brussels understands that the region's stability depends on a balanced relationship between Denmark's interests, the aspirations of the Greenlandic population and the need to avoid external interference that could compromise European security. Thus, the EU's position regarding the American interest in Greenland is based on three fundamental principles; the uncompromising defense of the sovereignty of a Member State; the preservation of stability and cooperation in the Arctic; and the protection of European strategic interests in critical resources and regional security. Trump's statements in Davos reinforced the European perception that the issue goes beyond a mere territorial dispute, revealing an assertive American strategy that combines economic pressure, historical narrative and geopolitical ambition. Although it recognizes the importance of the transatlantic partnership, the EU rejects unilateral approaches that could weaken the European political balance or transform the Arctic into a stage for confrontation between great powers. Greenland, located between continents and between logics of power, has become a test of the EU's ability to assert its strategic autonomy and protect its members in an increasingly competitive international context.

item.title: The Prince of Denmark
item.description: This is an unpredictable and strange time of ours, but it is still at the level of comedy with scarlet hints of narrative. Very discursive, unspeakable in its eagerness to justify itself. Let's say that we don't feel any confidence in the fictional interpretations that each and every person wishes to transmit, nothing that narrates the genre that they insist on interpreting in an abuse of power for a non-fictional reality. There is undoubtedly a fictional paranoia in Europe that makes it the agent of something that tends not only to go wrong, but also to dilute it, a rinse of nervousness in a secret reigning madness. But what do the most elusive do? They play narratively like a cat with a full belly plays with a mouse: tormenting, and finally letting it go in an inglorious fight.
