A barbaric signature that persists in legends and also in the weak imagination that is Europe today on the political and strategic narrative path that begins to poison the reigning acoustics. Now, Hamlet follows the guidelines of a ghost, but destiny reveals itself to be much more ghostly in its definitions, and if the penguins are far from these white areas, there are those who see them as being outside of their habitat – these beings as tender as doves and with unusual loyalty – and in an immense and unrecognizable bad narrative we now find the soul of Claudius, the uncle that no family wants to find. It is not the mermaid of Copenhagen, but the Prince of Denmark may or may not be, our closest “narrative”. Do it with respect. item.title: Timorese Maria do Céu Lopes protects heritage of ‘tais’, traditional fabrics
item.description: East Timorese Maria do Céu Lopes discovered the cultural importance of ‘tais’, cloths woven by women, in Timor-Leste during the war and cooperation with the resistance and today protects almost 400 examples, while waiting for a museum. Although he used 'tais' in some ceremonies during his childhood, it was only later, with his cooperation with the resistance and his curiosity, that he discovered its profound cultural value. Then comes the challenge of a childhood friend, António Coelho, specialized in fabrics, to preserve the ‘tais’. It was with his colleague that he began studies to collect information about those aspects associated with all the important moments in the life of a Timorese, but along the way he created, in 1999, Timor Aid, a non-governmental organization to protect the Timorese cultural heritage. “Timor Aid managed to do it, we have a collection of almost 400 pieces, some old, some copies of the old ones that we saw in the book that António gave us”, Maria do Céu Lopes told Lusa. In addition to collecting oral information, Timor Aid also documented in audiovisual the entire traditional process of producing a 'tais', including how cotton is dyed from natural plants, established a network of weavers to protect the tradition of confection and also a store in Dili. UNESCO recognition Their effort, out of “faith and conviction”, was recognized when the ‘tais’ was inscribed in 2021 on the List of Intangible Cultural Heritage in Need of Urgent Safeguarding of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO). “The recognition, the merit, is not ours, it belongs to the weavers and our ancestors”, he stated. Maria do Céu Lopes explained that that textile has a “very important role in Timorese domestic life”, in addition to identifying the linguistic group of those who use it and the community to which they belong. “The ‘tais’ is used from life to death, when a child is born the first thing to do is wrap it in a ‘tais’ and then so on: ‘barlaques’ [a type of dowry], funerals, the ritual ceremonies of ‘uma lulik’ [sacred houses]”, he said. “A woman, in ancient times, her dignity, her social position, was due to the ‘tais’ that she wove, because nowadays the ‘tais’ has value in money, but in the past it was in buffaloes, ‘morten’, traditional necklaces, ‘belak’ [used in necklaces] and gold”, he highlighted. Asked by Lusa about whether ‘tais’ could be lost, Maria do Céu Lopes considered that it could not. “But, the quality of modern ‘such’, few are good”, he lamented, highlighting that it is necessary to certify the product due to prices and for people to have the guarantee of what they are buying. Maria do Céu Lopes also lamented the lack of a museum to showcase Timorese heritage, which is seen in museums abroad, giving the Louvre as an example. “You want a museum, I want a museum because I have the material to put it in, it’s not for me it’s for Timor-Leste, we don’t have a decent cultural center, not even in Dili”, he lamented. "We don't do anything here. I can't build a museum, I don't have money," he added. While waiting for the museum, the Timor Aid collection will continue to be protected and waiting for dignity to be seen by the tourists, which Timor-Leste intends to attract.

item.title: K-Pop | Mark Tuan performs at Studio City in March
item.description: Mark Tuan, singer of the K-Pop group GOT7, performs in Macau on March 28th at the concert “Silhouette: The Shape of You FANCON ENCORE”, presenting songs from the new album with the same name. Tickets have been on sale since Friday On March 28th, the Studio City Event Center hosts what promises to be a great show for K-Pop lovers. This is the performance of Mark Tuan, member of the famous group GOT7, who is presenting the concert “MARK TUAN – Silhouette: The Shape of You FANCON ENCORE”, which aims to “celebrate Mark's musical evolution, offering an intimate vision of a personal journey of growth” of the musician in the world of shows and records, describes a statement from Studio City. Tickets have been on sale since Friday the 13th, with prices varying between MOP899 and MOP2,199, and all ticket holders can have access to an additional offer, namely an autographed poster and “the opportunity to participate in a ‘Hi-Bye’ session, offering an interactive experience that goes beyond expectations”, it is revealed. The show, in a format closer to the fans, will show how Mark Tuan has, as a singer and songwriter, “continued to expand musical boundaries”, developing “a distinct style in recent years that combines alternative rock with pop influences”. Mark Tuan has been on the road with this tour for a long time, now ending in Macau. Such a show will “further enrich the city’s live entertainment panorama, providing the public with high-quality cultural experiences”, describes Studio City. Songs in the scream This is also an opportunity for Mark Tuan to present his second mini-album, “Silhouette”, which features the emotionally charged lead single, “Sunsets and Cigarettes”; and a “tender serenade” called “Pretty Little Picture”. This is followed by the “visionary” song called “Autopilot”. This record is like “a private diary”, capturing “[Mark Tuan’s] transition and transformation through music and images, offering a glimpse of the path forward in his musical evolution”. GOT7 was born in South Korea in 2014, under the umbrella of JYP Entertainment, and has seven singers, one of them Mark Tuan, who has excelled in a solo career.

item.title: Artistic expressions of the Maritime Silk Road on display
item.description: The exhibition “Talent Training on the Cultural and Creative Design of Maritime Silk Road” can be visited until March 8th, in the Barra area, which was born from a project with the same name carried out by the Poly MGM Museum. This project was financed by the National Fund for the Arts of China. The exhibition reveals the creative works of 30 participants in the aforementioned program, which took place at the museum over the course of a year and, according to an official statement, is divided into six thematic chapters, revealing “diverse explorations of the Maritime Silk Road through cultural interpretation, design translation and contemporary artistic expression”. The public can view “30 original works spanning cultural and creative products, fashion design, painting, sculpture and multimedia installations”, demonstrating “the creative transformation from tradition to contemporary times, whilst injecting renewed artistic vitality into the historically rich district of Barra”. The program developed at the Poly MGM Museum included the collaboration of the teaching team at the Palace Museum and the Beijing Institute of Fashion Technology. It was a program that brought together “cultural theory, field studies and design practice”, bringing “a new impulse in the training of local cultural and creative talents”. A certain spirit Quoted in the same note, Pansy Ho, president and CEO of MGM China Holdings, said that “participants [of this project] embraced the spirit of the Maritime Silk Road, translating history and culture into works of contemporary aesthetic value and cultural confidence”. What happened at this exhibition, in his view, was a fusion of “traditional heritage” with “modern expression”, with Pansy Ho guaranteeing that the gaming operator “will continue to use Macau as a bridge to promote Chinese culture, not just as an enchanting ‘vision of the East’, but as a lifestyle and an aesthetic choice that truly enters the hearts, allowing Chinese civilization to radiate a new brilliance in our modern era”. Jia Ronglin, vice-president of the Beijing Institute of Fashion Technology, declared that Macau “exemplifies the meeting and coexistence of Eastern and Western civilizations”. “Based on its role as a cultural crossroads, this program deepens mutual understanding along the Maritime Silk Road, promotes design innovation and talent training, and revitalizes ancient wisdom and aesthetics in a contemporary context,” he said.

item.title: Chinese New Year | FRC presents exhibition with Cavalo as protagonist
item.description: “The Gallop of the Year of the Fire Horse” is the name of the exhibition that the Rui Cunha Foundation has been presenting in its gallery since Tuesday, and which celebrates the arrival of a new year in the Chinese calendar. The public can view, for four weeks, 26 works of art by Chinese and Portuguese artists in an exhibition organized in partnership with the Associação de Poesia dos Amigos do Jardim da Flora The Rui Cunha Foundation (FRC) gallery has the exhibition “The Gallop of the Year of the Fire Horse”, which aims to celebrate the arrival of the Year of the Horse with 26 artistic works. According to an official statement, the exhibition has been available for public viewing since Tuesday, featuring “26 eclectic works” created by Portuguese and Chinese artists, namely Lei Iat Po, Natalie Lao, Lee Chau Ping, He Jianguo, Liu Shengli, Wilson Lam, Li Jinxiang, Meng Li, or Lei Pui Seong, alongside names such as Paulo Valentim, Arlinda Frota, Rui Calado, Vasco d’Orey Bobone. It is a set of works previously created by artists “who passed through the [FRC] Gallery over almost fourteen years”, forming part of the FRC collection. The initiative was organized in partnership with the Associação de Poesia dos Amigos do Jardim da Flora, “which dedicated calligraphed verses of good auspices to this event”. The works on display consist of a “diverse set of works with oriental influence”, with this exhibition proposing “a visual and cultural journey through different artistic expressions, such as calligraphy, painting, sculpture and ceramics, exploring themes such as movement, energy, spirituality and renewal, values ​​intrinsically linked to this ancient celebration”. An ongoing dialogue The FRC describes that this set of artistic works reflects “the dialogue between cultures, traditions, artistic languages ​​and different materials, highlighting the fusion of this symbolic richness associated with the festive season of the lunar calendar”. With this exhibition, the FRC says it wants to “reinforce its commitment to the dissemination of art and the promotion of encounters between local artists from different cultures, emblematically marking the union of Macau society around the celebrations of each historical date or local anniversary”.

item.title: Study warns of cognitive impact of short videos on children
item.description: Two researchers from the University of Macau concluded that short-form videos used on social media and viewed on “scrolling” on cell phones negatively impact children's cognitive development, potentially causing social anxiety and insecurity. “Compulsive consumption of short videos has a negative impact on cognitive development, which can cause lack of concentration, social anxiety and self-doubt”, he explained to Lusa Wang Wei, academic in the field of Educational Psychology at the University of Macau (UM), author of the study “Addiction to short videos, school involvement and social inclusion among Chinese rural students”. “This short video design can be particularly dangerous for children”, warned the researcher. “Our research indicates a direct correlation: the more students consume short videos, the less they engage with school,” Wang continued. Wang argues that, although children's fundamental psychological needs must be met offline, the architecture of short video platforms, with personalized algorithms and social interaction features, directly and subtly meets these same needs. This parallel satisfaction, Wang's research suggests, “potentially leads to overuse and addiction.” “The stimulating and fast-paced nature of short videos makes them highly entertaining for students,” the researcher added. Attention required Anise Wu Man Sze, professor of Psychology at UM's Faculty of Social Sciences and author of the study “The relationship of affective and cognitive components in the problematic use of short videos”, adds to Wang's conclusions the issues related to the overstimulation of children, which further harm healthy cognitive development. The short videos capture everyone's attention precisely because “they are right there at hand and they are free”, highlights Wu, speaking to Lusa. People can access vast amounts of short videos “anytime, anywhere”. Now, these addictive behaviors often originate from a “functional purpose”, he explained. “We have to raise awareness, especially if use starts to affect daily life, leading to the sacrifice of family time, neglect of sleep, or people surfing at inappropriate times, such as during classes or driving, putting themselves or others at risk,” he told Lusa. As for interventions with children, according to Wang Wei, “it is very important” to satisfy their emotional needs, while cultivating digital literacy and self-regulation skills, “instead of limiting ourselves to taking away their cell phone”. By December 2024, the number of people with access to this type of videos in China reached close to 1.1 billion individuals, with 98.4 percent being active users of this format, according to the Annual Report on the Development of Audiovisual Services on the Internet, published by the Chinese authorities.

item.title: Restoration | After Macau, Manteigaria moves to Hong Kong
item.description: Manteigaria is linked to the Portugália Restauração Group and aims to open at least three stores in the HKSAR within a year. However, the future could lead to expansion into more markets, such as Mainland China, South Korea or Japan The Portugália Restauração Group will open the first store in Hong Kong of Manteigaria – Fábrica de Pastéis de Nata in April, the group's managing partner in Macau told Lusa. "It's a real and ongoing project. It's been a little delayed, but we already have the space identified [and] it will go into construction right after Chinese New Year", in the Central area of ​​Hong Kong Island, said Diogo Vieira. The Lunar New Year holiday period, the scene of the largest annual migration in the world, takes place this year between February 15th and 23rd in mainland China. “We are very excited and very happy to be able to enter that market, which has a different dynamic”, said the managing partner of Grupo Portugália Restauração in Macau. Vieira highlighted that Manteigaria has bigger plans for Hong Kong, “a city with at least seven million inhabitants, with a very large area, with many tourists, with very populated areas, where it is possible to expand quickly”. “It is the brand's objective, within a year, after opening the first one, to be able to open at least three stores in different locations in Hong Kong”, revealed the executive. Show Portugal “We want to show locals and tourists who visit Hong Kong that it is possible to have a product that comes from Portugal (…) and show the manufacturing, the Portuguese tradition”, said Vieira. After Hong Kong, the executive revealed, Manteigaria's “expansion project” will look at “other surrounding markets”, including mainland China, South Korea, Singapore and Thailand. The brand opened its first store in downtown Macau in January 2025, followed by a second store on the island of Taipa in November, and, said Vieira, currently employs “between 25 and 30 people”, selling an average of 2,500 pastries per day. Manteigaria's operation in Macau “is profitable and growing, therefore, the investment is expected to be recovered in a very short time”, added the group's managing partner. Macau had local custard tarts on the market, inspired by the Portuguese pastry, recreated by a British man living in the city, Andrew Stow (1955-2006). Although this is “an advantage”, Vieira says that “the necessary adjustments were made (…) to market needs, desires and local culture”, with a reduction by half of the sugar used in the pastel de nata recipe. In October, the Macau Government inscribed 12 events, including local pastéis de nata and Portuguese folk dance, on the territory's Intangible Cultural Heritage List. A decision that will also benefit the Portuguese pastry, defended Vieira. “We with the original Portuguese version, the other local producers with the Macau version, but we all compete a little in the same environment and in a very similar product and we all end up benefiting”, said the executive.

item.title: Operator Melco's profits quadruple in 2025
item.description: Macau casino operator Melco Resorts and Entertainment announced profits of US$185 million in 2025, four times more than the previous year. In a statement sent to the stock exchange in New York, the president of Melco, Lawrence Ho Yau Lung, says that “2025 was a year of growth and recovery, driven by disciplined cost management and the expansion of margins”. The company's revenues increased 11.2 percent, to $5.16 billion, despite closing the Grand Dragon Casino, a 'satellite casino', and three of the six gaming machine rooms it owned in 2025. The 'satellite casinos', under the responsibility of the concessionaires, are managed by other companies, being a legacy of the past that already existed before the liberalization of gambling in the territory, in 2002. When the legislation regulating casinos was changed, in 2022, the end of 2025 was established as the deadline for ending the activity of these gambling spaces. Ten of the 11 'satellite casinos' closed their doors. The only survivor was Royal Arc, which was acquired by operator SJM, founded by the late gaming mogul Stanley Ho Hung Sun, who took over direct management of the space. High pace Melco's revenues rose faster than the sector in general. Macau casino revenues grew 9.1 percent in 2025, reaching 247.4 billion patacas. Lawrence Ho, son of Stanley Ho, highlighted that the company's operating profit in Macau rose 25 percent last year, to US$1.23 billion, “driven by more robust gaming revenues and margins”. Melco operates in Macau, as well as Cyprus and the Philippines, having opened a casino in Sri Lanka in August. Melco expects to spend around 10 billion patacas in the non-casino segment within a decade, including on “the only water park in Macau with indoor facilities open all year round”. The company highlighted the relaunch, in May, at the City of Dreams hotel-casino, of the largest permanent show in the territory, The House of Dancing Water, which had been suspended since June 2020, due to the covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: Wynn | Operator's profit shrinks 7.7% in 2025
item.description: Despite the drop in profits, the concessionaire declared itself optimistic about the future of Macau's main industry. One of the reasons for optimism is the increase in betting in all market segments Casino operator Wynn Macau announced operating profits of US$1.09 billion in 2025, a drop of 7.7 percent. Wynn's revenues shrank even though revenues from the company's two properties in Macau increased 0.97 percent compared to 2024, to $3.72 billion, according to a statement from the operator. Betting at the Wynn Macau and Wynn Palace casinos accounted for the majority of the company's turnover in 2025, generating US$3.13 billion in revenue, an increase of 3.5 percent. The results “reflect continued strength across all sectors of the company and steady progress in our global development initiatives,” said Craig Billings, CEO of parent company Wynn Resorts, cited in the same statement. The North American group operates in Macau, as well as in the United States and the United Kingdom, and is also building a casino in the United Arab Emirates. “In Macau, we saw substantial increases in both VIP and mass market betting, compared to the previous year and also compared to the previous quarter,” said Billings, referring to the last quarter of 2025. In the segment known as VIP gaming, bets from high-rollers rose 15.9 percent at Wynn Macau's two casinos, but revenue increased much less, 0.93 percent, to $632.7 million. On average, casinos operating in Macau will seek 3 percent of VIP game bets, but by 2025 this figure has dropped to 2.55 percent in the case of Wynn Macau. Domination of the masses The so-called mass market continued to be, by far, the main segment for the operator, representing revenues of 2.92 billion dollars, 2.4 percent more than in 2024. In 2019, the so-called VIP baccarat game accounted for 46.2 percent of Macau's total casino revenue. But in 2025 this segment was left with a share of 27.5 percent, despite absolute revenues having increased by 24.1 percent. Big bets were affected by the arrest of the leader of the largest VIP betting company in the world, in November 2021. Alvin Chau Cheok Wa, former executive director of Suncity, was sentenced in January 2023 to 18 years in prison, in a case that saw the number of gambling promoter licenses issued in Macau drop from 85 to 18. In a conference call with investors, held after the results were announced, Craig Billings said that “the good momentum in Macau has continued” in 2026, with turnover “slightly above” that recorded at the end of last year. “We remain optimistic about the future of Macau,” said the executive.

item.title: Financing | Bad credit rising
item.description: In December last year, the unpaid debt ratio for housing mortgage loans increased by 0.1 percentage points, in annual terms, to 3.6 percent, according to data from the Macau Monetary Authority (AMCM). Between November and December, non-performing loans for housing loans decreased by 0.2 percentage points. With regard to commercial loans for real estate activities, non-performing loans also increased annually by 0.1 percentage points, to 5.4 percent. In December, new loans for the purchase of housing totaled 898.36 million patacas, an annual reduction of 11.0 percent and a monthly reduction of 28.2 percent. Income | Most expensive houses in 2025 Last year, the average rent per square meter, measured by the usable area, of housing reached 139 patacas, which represented an annual increase of 2.1 percent, according to data from the Statistics and Census Services Directorate (DSEC). The areas where housing rents rose the most were in Coloane (152 patacas), Zona de Aterros do Porto Exterior (ZAPE), an average of 120 patacas, and Baixa da Taipa (140 patacas), with an increase of 3.5 percent. However, the average rent of stores fell by 1.7 percent annually, to 469 patacas, while office rents registered an annual reduction of 4.8 percent, to 281 patacas. In relation to industrial zones, rents fell 2.3 percent in the space of a year, to 120 patacas. Foreign Exchange Reserves | January starts with reduction In January, the Macao SAR's foreign exchange reserves showed a reduction of 1.5 percent, compared to the value calculated, and rectified, in December of last year. The information was released by the Macau Monetary Authority, with the value of the reserve standing at 241.8 billion patacas at the end of January. The effective exchange rate of the Macau pataca, weighted by its trade shares, was 100.5 in January 2026, which represented a decrease of 0.65 points compared to December, and a reduction of 7.08 points compared to January 2025. Given this variation, the AMCM explained that “globally, the Macau pataca fell compared to the currencies of the main trading partners”.

item.title: GDP | Macau with the second highest per capita value in Asia
item.description: Although GDP per capita has exceeded 600 thousand patacas, it is still far from the record value of 2014, when it reached more than 705 thousand patacas Macau's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) per capita grew 4.3 percent in 2025, it was announced on Friday, surpassing 600,000 patacas, the second highest value in Asia. Detailed data released by the Statistics and Census Bureau (DSEC) reveals that the region's GDP per capita reached 607,263 patacas last year. According to data from the Monetary Fund, Macau has the second highest GDP per capita in Asia, behind only Singapore, and ranks 11th among the richest jurisdictions in the world. Despite having grown for the third consecutive year – thanks to the end of restrictions imposed due to the pandemic – the territory's GDP per capita remains far below the record of 705,535 patacas set in 2014. After growing 8.8 percent in 2024, the economy of Macau – the world's gambling capital and the only place in China where it is legal – slowed to an expansion of 4.7 percent last year, supported mainly by casinos. The economic benefit of gambling increased by 10 percent in 2025, reaching 198.1 billion patacas, representing almost half (47.3 percent) of the city's entire GDP. If casinos are added to the economic benefit of tourism, which grew 0.1 percent last year, to 111.6 billion patacas, then this sector accounts for 74.1 percent of Macau's economy. Far from other times Macau's GDP in 2025 reached 418 billion patacas. This means that the local economy is still 10.4 percent smaller than in 2019, before the pandemic began. On Wednesday, Fitch said it expects Macau to continue to boost the development of other sectors, namely “deepening integration” with the neighboring special economic zone of Ilha da Montanha. However, the financial rating agency warned that restrictions on labor from abroad and a lack of qualified personnel are holding back the diversification of the region's economy. But Fitch warned that human resources “will constrain Macau’s ability to build a competitive advantage in emerging non-gaming sectors in the near term.” At the end of 2025, the region employed almost 184 thousand migrant workers, an increase of almost 32 thousand since the end of the 'zero covid' policy, in January 2023, but still far from the maximum peak of 196,538, reached at the end of 2019. Macau authorities have highlighted economic relations with Portuguese-speaking countries as one of the priorities to reduce dependence on casinos. In December, Fitch predicted that the territory's GDP growth will slow to 4 percent in 2026 as weaker economic conditions will "increasingly weigh on Chinese tourists."

item.title: Chinese New Year | Expected 670 thousand daily border crossings
item.description: Macau expects 670,000 daily border crossings, and more than six million entries and exits during the Lunar New Year period, when the largest annual migration in the world takes place, it was announced yesterday. The Public Security Police Corps (CPSP) said that between the 15th and 23rd of February “a total of between 6 and 6.21 million is estimated” of border crossings, with the peak expected to be around 780 thousand people on the 19th of February. “Macau has many activities taking place at this time, we always take measures to control the flow [of people] during this time”, announced Lei Tak Fai, deputy head of the Operations Planning Department. On Sunday, Macau recorded a new all-time high in entries and exits at the borders, with ten days left until the Lunar New Year, with around 867 thousand crossings. According to PSP data, the largest border in the territory, at Portas do Cerco, registered the passage of almost 463 thousand people, the highest daily figure in the last five years, since the beginning of the covid-19 pandemic. In the neighboring Chinese region of Hong Kong, Secretary for Culture, Sports and Tourism, Rosanna Law Shuk-pui, predicted last Saturday that 1.43 million people from mainland China are expected to visit the city during the Lunar New Year holidays.

item.title: ZELENSKY VS ZELENSKY
item.description:
10/27/22 A Ukrainian pensioner, with the same name as the president, blames Zelensky for the prolongation of the conflict that destroyed his village. Zelensky, the villager, who never left his land, is now mortified because his favorite gravedigger died in the bomber. This Zelensky, a villager, represents half the world that recriminates the other Zelensky, the villain, for not wanting to negotiate with Putin. Negotiate what? The invader enters our house, covers his wife and daughter (cf. recent UN report on the rapes in Ukraine, in this “special operation”), an act that forced us to watch, and then we say to him: hi there, we are for peace, but we have to negotiate: you still haven't said what name you want to give the children! A peace that is not dignified is nothing more than a cessation of rights. As serious as the Russophobia that Putin inflicts on his people.
10/28/22 At a lunch with several guests, I heard a friend, who declared herself a spiritualist, explaining the particularities of her belief, in a calm and balanced way, I would even say, without a hint of “irrationalism”. He spoke at length and serenely, devoid of any fanatical proselytism. “Here is someone whose belief has brought thoughtfulness!” I thought, a rare alliance. However, at a certain moment a sentence comes out that horrifies me. It says, “there is no chance, nothing happens by chance!”, and I glimpse the voracious maws of holism. Because holism has a pathological aspect, like all good things, a shadow side. Two examples: in Hinduism there is less sensitivity to existential dramas, if that child suffers in this life this is just an expression of rigorous karmic symmetry, an effect of the acts he committed in his previous life. In Africa, it is not accepted that death could have been accidental, and many women are accused by the family of the deceased of having caused the death of their husband, in an act of manifest dementia, and, in the blatant majority of cases, a huge injustice for the wife — madness that spreads and infiltrates the social fabric. Buddhism introduced Compassion and Christianity introduced Caritas, trying to break with this logic, but in many other beliefs and religions the cage of causalities prevails over sensitivity to experience, the need to respond to the now. It is a tremendous logic that transforms the world into a Platonic stage, where we are nothing more than the shadows of something — an inextricable law -, in a determinism that calcifies all singularities, but that strangely fascinates many. The conquest of modernity was anchored in the conquest of chance and randomness, removing the incidences of a life from this fierce determinism that enclosed the world in a web. When the Renaissance freed the body from the influence of the stars, at that moment sexuality was relieved of guilt and individualism and its volition were able to emerge. There is an unequivocal moral implication in the phrase “there is no such thing as chance, nothing happens by chance!”, which should function as a key to self-knowledge and self-judgment, however, this phrase is usually used to seek a reason for things outside of us, in others. It's an alibi. Today there is a holistic temptation in the world, just as there was a satanic temptation in the Middle Ages, without much reflection on its consequences. Because it's not enough to want to connect everything in a resonant chain of affection. Even for the most unexpected: affection itself can kill. I realize, thanks to that cultured, balanced, intelligent woman, that “the fight” took place at the beginning of this century. One of the great mistakes of the 20th century was the false dichotomy between “rationalism and irrationalism”, a debate that extended to all fields, including art. First, rationality (the positive side of reason) was confused with rationalism (the pathological aspect of reason), and articulated in this lack of discernment, irrationalism was confused with freedom. Almost all 20th century art, with Surrealism at its head, made this mistake. The fallacy still exists despite the emergence of “irrationalism” and the consequent relativist currents that followed it having been consolidated everywhere. Essentially, much of what happened in the 20th century revolved around this clash between two paradigms: Rationalism versus Irationalism. Now, I see, we must save indeterminacy, chance, randomness from the terrible temptation of the cage of causalities. Holism, in its pathological form, may be reductionism that sets itself up as a new “eschatological narrative”. Is it “by chance” that holism emerges at a time when neo-liberalism and its cynical contempt for the human person is besieging everything, all freedoms, all acquired rights? Holistic awareness has brought a positive impact to greater ecological awareness, but followed with scholastic rigor, it stifles reality under the blanket of a determinism that is much more than uncomfortable: all great authoritarian ideologies are holistic. My friend will know how to combine her holistic and transpersonal belief with the freedom and responsibility that each moment asks of us — but how many will make the distinction, under a Law that explains and encompasses everything? How many will abandon themselves to what is? The awareness of the indeterminate brings tragic awareness, as the Greeks knew, but it also brings agency and the courage of decision. And we cannot give up on this. Furthermore, as Drummond shows in the poem “Quadrilha”, by Carlos Drummond de Andrade: «João loved Teresa who loved Raimundo/ who loved Maria who loved Joaquim who loved Lili/ who didn't love anyone./ João went to the United States, Teresa to the convent,/ Raimundo died of a disaster, Maria stayed with her aunt,/ Joaquim committed suicide and Lili married J. Pinto Fernandes/ who had not entered the story.» Real always runs outside the track, completely outside our concepts. That's what matters to us — a J. Pinto Fernandes emerges at the exact moment when we thought we had everything under control.

item.title: From Nobel and others
item.description: 9/10/22 When reading many people's reactions when this year's Nobel Prize for Literature was announced, I couldn't help but remember this comment from Jean-Pierre Siméon, in relation to another Nobel Prize: «An editor of a large national daily newspaper wrote five lines of indignation at the fact that the Nobel Prize for Literature had been awarded to Thomas Traströmer, a complete stranger. But unknown to whom? How did it not occur to this literary columnist, patented and paid to do his job, that his apparent ignorance was a matter of professional misconduct? Tranströmer had been translated into many languages, it was available in French.» There is always the chorus of those who wait for the Prize to be announced to complain about not having been invited to be on the jury, there is a subgroup of angry people who profess “I have never read it and I won’t even bother to read it”; It is a less than humble fauna, the one that inhabits social networks. I don't always know all the winners – I didn't know about the existence of Louise Glück, who I think is a great poet, or Olga Tokarczuk, for example – but this only brings me the comfort of knowing that the world is not a soap opera where everyone knows everyone else and the joy of recognizing that the yardstick of the world is not measured with my short measure and that, on the contrary, it gives me a new opportunity to face the unknown and learn from it. And perhaps the most stupid reaction was that of the intelligent man who wrote, But are there still people who read French?; simply confirming that today there is a new type of ignorance that is being raised with abandon: that of those who only read English. I would also prefer that, in French, Pascal Quignard, Linda Lê or even Sollers were awarded, or, among the new ones, Mathias Énard, but that does not detract from the dignity of Annie Ernaux's work (and it would have been enough to have written “Les Années”). There are books of hers that I like less, like the vulgar “Uma Paixão Simples”, but that happens with almost all authors, they have pivotal books and others that are like breaks in their itinerary. I recommend reading a beautiful book of interviews with her, “L’écriture comme un couteau”. 11/10/22 Yesterday an article appeared in the morning newspaper “Notícias”, in Maputo, reporting that the Pen Club Narrative Prize had been awarded to my wife, Teresa Noronha, for her soap opera “Tornado”, which had already won the Maria Velho da Costa Prize. The summary they made of the book does not even deserve comments, as it is pathetic, but what is important to highlight is the note of disqualification regarding its “Mozambicanness” when they call it Luso-Mozambican. It's not that it's inaccurate, but, for those who know the context, it's a touch naughty. Because finally, following the same logic, Adelino Timóteo should be called Tsonga-Mozambican, Álvaro Taruma Ronga-Mozambican, and Macua-Mozambican for writers from the north, etc., etc. Which doesn't appear to happen. At one point, in the novel, she writes: «Our color was never the dominant one. In colonial times we were not white, we were dressed in monhés, mugs of washed asses, the pejorative term to speak of a son of Goan and Portuguese. In the post-colonial period, I was not black and if, in Lisbon, they took me for Brazilian or Cape Verdean, in France they were lost in thought about where I was from and were surprised when they discovered that I was African. There I had to explain the wanderings of my DNA before settling in Mozambique. It took me a long time to accept that it was like that because yes, and that it was no curse that that was the case; on the contrary, I could even discover intense patterns of fantasy and freedom in this harlequin cloak that is our genealogy…” In modern-day Mozambique, it means being white… and that immediately takes precedence over what you do or what you are. It's sad, but as Naipaul warned, in these parts race is everything and people live as deeply immersed in it as, in other places, in religion. 12/10/22 Bruno Latour, an anthropologist who studied the sciences and their procedures and legitimations, law, technique and religions and who entertained himself by turning his back on the dogmas of the “moderns”, has died. For him, the place, the role of the specialist, was defined more by the perplexity he embodied than by the supposed truth that would sustain him. He proposed, as an alternative to the goodness of multiculturalism and its equivocal cliché “all different, all equal”, a return to “diplomacy”, given that this, precisely, does not start from the assumption that “we are unified because we share the same nature” but simply highlights that we “still do not share a common world”; It is necessary that we deal head-on with the “abyss of disagreement” that separates us, instead of trying to deceive it. And about politics he said, boldly: «If transparency is demanded from politicians, we kill them; if anyone demands fidelity to what the other was or what he says, kill him; If a mimetic relationship is required between what the crowd wants and what its representative says, representation is killed. These must therefore, by definition, betray, deceive, modify, distort the word. Without this ability to bend the word and betray, political language would not exist. I put forward the perfectly plausible hypothesis that political vocabulary will become as inaccessible as the religious language of the last twenty, three or fifty years.» (in “Un Monde Pluriel mais Commun”). I believe we will be needed to decipher this frantically complex world that has fallen to us.

item.title: Fuxi
item.description: O my friends, companions of these disastrous journeys through countries as old as the stars and the Moon, and as strange as the deepest interior of our wretched souls, what surprises still await us, what secret magics will we still have to overcome, what horrors will arise before our pupils dilated with astonishment and terror? Increasingly closer to our precarious existences, howls the monster of war, which threatens to merge humanity once and for all with the earth, incessantly traversed by the squalid specter of hunger and the invisible evil of ten thousand pestilences. Oh damned human, who believes you are superior to Nature itself, but then you reveal yourself, time and time again, incapable of simply ordering your existence and do not understand that you are possessed by fickle anger and are a slave to your own ambition! You are not satisfied with white jade or resplendent gold, there is no treasure that quenches your inextinguishable thirst for command over other men, animals and things; for eternal anguish dwells in you; in you the expelled serpents crawl; for you grows, powerful and impressive, the most fertile ivy of Evil! This is perhaps why on the Mount they call the White Deer, where one of the eight immortals on a sacred mount soared through the heavens towards Penglai, lives the fuxi, a bird whose shape resembles that of a rooster, although topped by a human head. What strange copulations, what monstrous embraces, what terrible procedures must have occurred to make the existence of this sinister animal possible? We don't know, but all it takes is for our exhausted mind to dare to come up with an answer, and then we feel our skin covered in horrendous goosebumps and our heart races in parade, like a wild horse whipped by the night whip of fear, unresponsive to reins and containment. Let men refrain from visiting Monte do Veado, because although there are riches capable of calming the wildest ambitions, if they have the unfortunate luck of catching a glimpse of a fuxi, it is certain that a war will soon break out and the cultivated fields will perish, because of it the tame animals will be beheaded, because of it the best young men of two generations will be sacrificed and the pride of the countries will be destroyed. The fuxi makes a sound reminiscent of its name. If you hear it, dark night or clear day, be on your way, because the path you are on is the surest path to misfortune!

item.title: Procrastinators Club
item.description: While rereading Easter, because of an article I'm preparing, I come across this excerpt, taken from “The Universal Man”: «Each man, morally, is one and absolute; but he has to live with attenuating his personality. (…) Coexistence is only possible between people reduced to a negative or hollow presence, which constantly gives way. Hence, the emptiness of society, an immense ghost made up of countless dead people. A superior man is antisocial or criminal. His destiny is prison and the desert”. I hesitate to think whether Pascoaes reflects here on the political-social conditions that muzzle, and, worse, in a sad country like Portugal in the middle of the Estado Novo (and the book is from 1931) where any possibilities of spontaneity and frankness in human relationships were restricted, or if it merely lends to the behavior of (oppressed) men a metaphysical framework, an “essence”, declared in the presumption of each being, in isolation, “one and absolute”. Sometimes, in addition to an excess of Spirituality (or Saudade), Pascoaes lacks the world. He is a great poet, but he is a poet who takes Ampoules-of-Great-Ideas and who therefore writes often trapped by a programmatic furor, ceasing to have pores; It is not uncommon for a glass to be erected between him and reality, the same glass that made him write in O Bailado, from 1921: «Everything is a ghost. There are only clouds, clouds of voices, clouds of souls, of afflictions and tragedies! Clouds and more clouds, appearances and more appearances! And a divine lightning that pierces them, the instantaneous Apparition that appears and throws us to the ground, dazzled!» Sometimes I felt like reminding him, as António Sérgio did, in the article “Regeneration and Tradition, Moral and Economy”, which he dedicated to Pascoaes: «Pascoais, Pascoais my dear friend: you are a pure, excellent and noble poet, but also a victim of this social environment, like us all: of this horrible isolation that you praise and I curse». «As a child, he stole two blackbirds», says Jacinto do Prado Coelho, he stole them from a nest, and he felt remorse for that all his life. The Person, few more mischiefs are known to him. Only in Álvaro de Campos does a hint of wickedness and obscenity emerge: «Ah, and the ordinary and dirty people, who always look the same,/ Who use swear words as usual words,/ Whose sons steal from grocery store doors/ And whose daughters at the age of eight – and I think this is beautiful and I love it! –/ Decent-looking men masturbate in stairwells.” (Triumphal ode). Both poets, driven by a certain idea of ​​sanctity, had the same inability to break the siege of their skin with the overflow of someone else's dam, the same curse of sublimating the concrete ferocity of eros with the gentleness of the verses. Obviously, they are both “bigger than life”, but sometimes it makes me unnerved to watch, from my position as a hatter at the Procrastinators Club, the tantrums between them, just to see who occupies, in the internal organization, the place of President and Treasurer. Although Pessoa guessed more things, for example, what he wrote in the lesser-known Ode Martial and which is reflected in the situation we live in today, in a different way, with his heart in his hands: «MARTIAL ODE (…) Helahoho! helahoho! The poor widow's sewing machine who was bayoneted... She sewed indefinitely in the afternoon… The table where the old people played, Everything mixed, everything mixed with bodies, with blood, All one river, one wave, one dragging horror. Helahoho! helahoho! I unearthed the child's tin train pressed into the middle of the [road, And I cried like all the mothers in the world about the horror of life. My pantheistic feet tripped over the sewing machine [widow who was killed with a bayonet And that poor instrument of peace stuck a spear in my heart. Yes, I was the one to blame for everything, I was the soldier for them all Who killed, raped, burned and broke, It was me and my shame and my remorse like a shadow [deformed They travel around the world like Ashavero, But behind my steps there are footsteps the size of infinity And a physical fear of being accountable to God makes me close my eyes. [eyes suddenly. (…) I ordered, captain, to shoot the trembling peasants, I let the daughters of all fathers tied to trees be raped, Now I saw that it was inside my heart that all this happened, And everything scalds and suffocates and I can't move without it [everything be the same. God have mercy on me, I didn't have it from anyone! LÀ-BAS, JE NE SAIS OÙ…” What is clear today, at this disastrous moment in which Cristiano & Companhia failed in their mission in Braga, and in which the self-sabotage of Russia's gas pipelines reminds us that Putin will be willing to do anything to maintain dominance over the areas endorsed, is that, bomb for bomb, the “bomb” of the Fifth Empire was preferable. However, even in this, my dears, we were irresolute, a little more on the side of piela than determined, and we procrastinated.

item.title: China asks US to make 2026 a year of “peaceful coexistence”
item.description: China and the US must make 2026 a year of convergence for “mutual respect, peaceful coexistence and mutually beneficial cooperation”, said the head of Chinese diplomacy, Wang Yi, to his US counterpart, Marco Rubio. Wang and Rubio met on Friday on the sidelines of the Munich Security Conference, according to a statement published Saturday on the official website of the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs. “Dialogue is better than confrontation, cooperation is better than conflict, and mutual gain is better than the zero-sum (mentality) in relations between China and the US,” said the Chinese foreign minister. Wang assured that, as long as Washington and Beijing “respect the principles of equality, respect and mutual benefit”, they will be able to “find ways” to resolve tensions and manage differences “appropriately”. “Both sides should work together to continuously expand the list of areas of cooperation and reduce the list of problems, so that China-US relations are on a stable, healthy and sustainable path of development, sending a positive message to the world,” added the head of Chinese diplomacy. Positive signs According to the statement, Wang and Rubio concluded that the meeting was “positive and constructive” and agreed to “facilitate high-level interactions” and “strengthen dialogue and cooperation in various areas.” The United States Department of State has not yet released any information about the meeting, nor has Rubio done so on social media. The meeting precedes the expected trip by North American President Donald Trump to China next April — the exact dates have not yet been confirmed — during which, according to the local press, an extension of the one-year trade truce that the Republican President sealed in October with his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, could be signed, after months of confrontation over tariffs. Furthermore, Trump recently stated that Xi will also visit the United States “later this year”, although this visit has not been officially confirmed either. The statement makes no reference to the issues addressed by the two presidents in a phone call last week, such as Taiwan, described by Xi as the “first red line” in relations with the United States, a subject he suggested to Trump to address “with the utmost prudence”, after the latest arms sale to the self-governed island. This Friday's meeting was the second in person between Wang and Rubio — sanctioned by China in 2020, when he was a senator from Florida, due to protests in Hong Kong and sanctions for Xinjiang —, after the meeting last July, on the sidelines of a summit of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

item.title: Kim Jong-un prepares to name daughter heir, writes Seoul
item.description: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un is preparing to name his daughter Ju-ae as successor, a deputy said after a meeting with the secret services, as he prepares for the grand power ceremony in Pyongyang this month. The Kim dynasty has ruled the country with an 'iron fist' since its founding in 1948, with Kim Jong-un succeeding his father and grandfather. The current leader, who maintains secrecy about his descendants, increasingly appears with his teenage daughter, Kim Ju-ae, at important official events, leading us to believe that she is the favorite for the succession. “South Korea's National Intelligence Service (NIS) estimates that Kim Ju-ae is about to be named successor,” Rep. Lee Seong-kweun said yesterday after a meeting with the NIS. The information is based, in particular, on a visit in January to the Kumsusan Sun Palace – where the founder Kim Il-sung and his son and second supreme leader, Kim Jong-il, rest -, during which Ju-ae paid homage to his ancestors alongside his father. Love Stories At the ruling party congress in Pyongyang at the end of the month, the Government is expected to reveal national guidelines, from foreign policy to the economy, including defense and advances in nuclear weapons. The meeting also often serves as a platform to announce changes in the leadership of the Workers' Party of Korea. Analysts believe that Ju-ae could be appointed first secretary of the central committee, that is, number two in the PTC. The existence of Kim Jong-un's daughter was revealed in 2022, when she watched with her father the launch of an intercontinental ballistic missile. Official North Korean media refer to Ju-ae as the country's “beloved daughter”, or even “great guide”, qualifications normally reserved for North Korea's supreme leaders and their heirs.

item.title: Public tenders | New plan to integrate AI into hiring
item.description: Chinese authorities yesterday released a strategy to accelerate the application of artificial intelligence (AI) in public tenders, with the aim of increasing efficiency, strengthening supervision and ensuring a “fair and efficient” distribution of public resources. The document, issued by the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC, China's main economic planning body) together with other state institutions, defines that, by the end of 2026, some provinces must fully implement features such as irregularity detection, AI-assisted evaluation and identification of collusion in tenders. The plan foresees the extension of these practices to the entire country by 2028. Among the planned applications, the following stand out: analysis of sectoral trends, balance between supply and demand and regulatory background checks to help define technical and commercial requirements during the preparatory phase of competitions. During the preparation of specifications, technology must allow the early detection of illegal clauses or clauses that restrict competition. Have sense On the competitors' side, AI will be able to support the preparation of proposals, the analysis of risks of contractual non-compliance and the verification of the documentation presented. The plan emphasizes, however, that conclusions generated by artificial intelligence systems do not replace the independent judgment of the parties involved nor do they exempt their respective legal responsibilities. Strict compliance with registration, review and security requirements for the algorithms used is also expected, to mitigate risks such as lack of transparency, errors or biases. The announcement comes amid the rapid expansion of the Chinese AI ecosystem, driven by the launch of advanced language models by companies such as Bytedance, DeepSeek, Alibaba and Baidu and growing political support for technological self-sufficiency. China seeks to consolidate its own capabilities in models, data and computational infrastructure, in a scenario of growing rivalry with the United States in the field of artificial intelligence.

item.title: Apple Daily | The dissolution of companies linked to the newspaper advances
item.description: The Hong Kong Government has begun the process to dissolve three companies linked to the now-defunct Apple Daily newspaper, founded by tycoon Jimmy Lai and closed in 2021 under the National Security Law, imposed by Beijing in 2020. Hong Kong Security Secretary Chris Tang sent written notices to Apple Daily Limited, Apple Daily Printing Limited and AD Internet Limited, giving them until February 25 to present their defense before recommending to the Chief Executive the deletion of these companies from the Commercial Register, read a Government statement. The three companies were previously convicted, along with Lai, of conspiracy to collude with foreign forces and of conspiring to publish seditious material, crimes covered by national security legislation. Each received a fine of 3,004,500 Hong Kong dollars. A spokesperson for the Security Secretariat invoked article 31 of the National Security Law, which allows the suspension of operations or the revocation of licenses of entities sanctioned by this rule. “Considering the seriousness of the crimes committed, it is considered necessary to prohibit the operation or continuity of these companies in Hong Kong to safeguard national sovereignty,” the spokesperson said in a statement. If the proposal is approved by the Chief Executive, the companies will be removed from the register and will be considered “prohibited organisations”. Anyone acting as a member or providing assistance to these entities could face fines of up to one million Hong Kong dollars and sentences of up to 14 years in prison. Apple Daily went out of business in June 2021 following a large-scale police raid, asset freeze and executive detention under the National Security Law. Lai, founder of the newspaper and symbol of dissent in Hong Kong, was sentenced to 20 years in prison last Monday, following the outcome of the same case.

item.title: West Bank | Beijing against annexation of Palestinian territory
item.description: China yesterday spoke out against “any attempt to annex” Palestinian territory, after Israel approved, on Sunday, measures that significantly strengthen its control over the occupied West Bank. “China has always opposed the construction of new colonies in the occupied Palestinian territories and any attempt to annex or usurp Palestinian territory that compromises the foundations of the two-state solution,” said Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Lin Jian at a press conference. The measures approved by the Israeli security cabinet over the weekend facilitate the purchase of land by settlers in the West Bank, occupied by Israel since 1967, and allow Israeli authorities to administer certain religious sites, even when they are located in areas under control of the Palestinian Authority. “The West Bank is an inalienable part of Palestinian territory,” Lin Jian reiterated. China reaffirms its defense of the political solution of two states – Israel and Palestine – coexisting peacefully and securely.

item.title: Nuclear | Moscow says it will continue to comply with the treaty if the US does so
item.description: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said yesterday that Moscow will continue to comply with the limits imposed on its nuclear arsenal, despite the recent end of the New START treaty, as long as the United States does the same. These restrictions “will remain in force, but only as long as the United States does not exceed the limits stipulated” in the treaty, Lavrov said in an intervention made yesterday in the Russian parliament. Moscow “will act in a responsible and considered manner, based on an analysis of US military policy (…) and an analysis of the general strategic situation”, he added. Russia and the United States have by far the largest nuclear arsenals in the world, but since the New START Treaty expired earlier this month, there is no nuclear disarmament agreement linking the two powers. The treaty, signed in 2010 between Russia and the United States, limited the number of nuclear missile launchers to intercontinental distances. It expired on February 5th, as US President Donald Trump did not respond to Moscow's proposal to extend it.

item.title: AI | Bytedance launches new model capable of generating more realistic videos
item.description: Technological advances are multiplying at a breakneck speed. ByteDance's new artificial intelligence model presents itself as a turning point in the film and television sectors Chinese technology company ByteDance has attracted the attention of users and investors after launching an artificial intelligence model for video generation that analysts say “exceeds expectations in terms of realism”. The new application, called Seedance 2.0, was launched this weekend, and its capabilities have already resulted in significant rises in the stock market for companies, not only in the technology sector, but also in the entertainment industry, with some of them reaching the daily earnings limit in recent sessions. According to economic news portal Caixin, this model is capable of generating realistic images with fluid movements, also adding sounds that coincide with the images, which for the first time puts ByteDance in a position to compete with KlingAI, developed by the short video platform Kuaishou. Feng Ji, producer of the popular video game Black Myth: Wukong, described Seedance 2.0 as “the most powerful video generation model yet,” and predicted a major impact on reducing production costs for film and television, as well as other types of content. The official Seedance 2.0 portal states that the big difference compared to similar models is its ability to maintain the coherence of the characters in different scenes. New chapter According to analysts at Kaiyuan Securities, cited by the Bloomberg agency, this new model could mark a turning point in the use of AI in film and television: "The test results are impressive. It supports text, image, video and audio input, and has achieved significant progress in crucial capabilities." Feng also warned of the risks of the proliferation of fake videos generated by these types of services, which could lead to a crisis of trust: “Realistic fake videos will be available to everyone, and intellectual property and supervision systems will face unprecedented challenges.” "In the future, any video content that does not have an official and authorized backing – especially those with personal images and voices – may be fake. Please be sure to verify them through multiple channels to avoid being scammed," the producer wrote on social media. Seedance 2.0 did not reach the market in isolation, as its great local rival, the aforementioned KlingAI, launched its 3.0 version on the 4th, with intelligent framing and the ability to add new images and people to the original video as major attractions.

item.title: CNOOC starts searching for hydrocarbons in Mozambique in March
item.description: The Mozambican Energy Minister, Estêvão Pale, assured that the Chinese state oil company CNOOC will begin exploring for hydrocarbons in March with the drilling of up to six blocks of the concession awarded in the sixth tender, launched in 2021. "They will start very soon. In March, they will start preparing to start exploration", said the Minister of Mineral Resources and Energy, Estêvão Pale, questioned by journalists at the Mining Indaba conference, which has been taking place since Monday in Cape Town, South Africa. “Right now, we are in the initial phase, five to six more blocks”, he also replied, regarding the drilling holes to be carried out by the Chinese National Offshore Oil Corporation (CNOOC) in deep waters of the Rovuma Basin, north of the country. The previous Mozambican Government approved on March 26, 2024 five terms of concession contracts for the production of hydrocarbons – essentially natural gas – in the country, the then spokesperson for the Council of Ministers announced at that time. “As part of the implementation of the mineral resources policy (…), the Government of Mozambique continued with actions aimed at seeking more investments for the oil sector”, said the Government spokesperson at that time. In December 2022, the National Petroleum Institute announced the award of these blocks to CNOOC, as a result of the sixth tender for gas and oil prospecting, launched on November 25, 2021. On the ground The current Minister of Energy, Estêvão Pale, questioned at the same event, assured that, for now, Mozambique has no plans for a new round of auctions for oil and gas blocks. "Not now, because we think that there are still many areas for direct negotiations, which were part of the last round, that have not been developed. We now have the opportunity to continue discussions and see if we can find another potential partner", he said. Mozambique has three development projects approved to explore natural gas reserves in the Rovuma basin, classified among the largest in the world, off the coast of Cabo Delgado. Eni's Coral Sul project is the only one in operation since 2022, and investment in a second floating platform for extraction, called Coral Norte, was approved last October, in an investment of 7.2 billion dollars, which from 2028 will allow production to be doubled to 7 million tons per year (mtpa) of liquefied natural gas. After four years of suspension due to the terrorist attacks in Cabo Delgado, the $20 billion Mozambique LNG project (Area 1), operated by TotalEnergies, officially resumed last January and is expected to produce up to 13 mtpa from 2029, followed by the $30 billion Rovuma LNG project (Area 4), operated by ExxonMobil, with 18 mtpa expected after 2030, and whose final investment decision is expected this year.

item.title: Economy | Inflation eases as food prices fall
item.description: Inflation in China slowed down in January, after reaching the highest value in the last three years in December, mainly influenced by the fall in food prices, according to official data released yesterday. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) rose 0.2 percent year-on-year in January, a slowdown from the 0.8 percent recorded in December, according to China's National Bureau of Statistics. Food prices fell 0.7 percent in January, reversing the 1.1 percent rise recorded in the previous month. The prices of non-food products rose 0.4 percent, less than the 0.8 percent in December. The underlying CPI, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, rose 0.8 percent year on year, after rising 1.2 percent in December. In monthly terms, the IPC registered a positive variation of 0.2 percent in January, the same value as in December. The data contradicts the deflationary cycle that has hit China for around two years. The Production Price Index (IPP) fell 1.4 percent in January compared to the same month last year, an improvement compared to the 1.9 percent drop in December, but remaining in deflationary territory for the 40th consecutive month.

item.title: Marcelo Loureiro, author and teacher: “The indigenato was a continuation of slavery”
item.description: He was recently in Macau to present the book “Colonial Citizenship: law, race and rights through the Portuguese empire”. Marcelo Loureiro's work explores the way in which, in the Portuguese empire, Portuguese citizenship was shaped according to skin color. Macau was no exception, although with different contours compared to Africa, argues the professor at the University of Leicester Image: Rui Cunha Foundation How did this investigation begin and how did the themes of colonialism and citizenship arise? Everything was born from a personal and family experience. I grew up in Rio de Janeiro, in a family marked by the Portuguese diaspora on the one hand, and colonial silence on the other. My paternal grandmother, Portuguese, kept the documents that allowed me, at the age of thirteen, to claim Portuguese citizenship in the back of a closet. My other grandmother, mestizo, cafuza, had no papers, no stories to tell; From her to me, there was only silence. This division, between those who have the right to documents and a voice and those who are forced to be erased, was the starting point for questioning the legal construction of citizenship and nationality. When I arrived in Portugal to study Law in Coimbra, I began to realize that the law that recognized me as Portuguese was the same one that historically denied this recognition to millions of people based on race, 'civilization' and skin color. The book is, in part, an attempt to understand this legal structure of inclusion and exclusion, it is a denunciation of the injustice behind rights. It is a denunciation of citizenship as a method of exclusion. In the context of the Portuguese empire, when did the first notions of citizenship emerge and what criteria were used? The first formal notions of national belonging in Portugal appear in the Philippine Ordinances of 1603, which establish who should be considered 'natural' of the kingdom. It is interesting to note that the inclusion of the notion of nationality was only included in Portuguese law during the Iberian Union, during the Philippine dynasty, when Spain controlled Portugal through the Habsburgs. It was in this context that Spanish law was transposed to Portugal to separate Portuguese from Spanish. However, the practical construction of Portuguese citizenship begins much earlier, in opposition: through slavery. Since the 15th century, with papal bulls (such as Dum Diversas of 1452 and Romanus Pontifex of 1454), Portugal obtained canonical legitimacy to enslave Africans and conquer their territories. Portuguese citizenship was thus constructed, in opposition to the figure of the ‘other’ – the Moor, the black, the pagan, the ‘savage’, and finally, the ‘indigenous’. What were the differentiation criteria? The criteria were essentially civilizational and racial: being Christian and, progressively, being white or recognized as ‘civilized’ according to European standards. Conversion to Christianity functioned, at times, as a kind of 'spiritual whitening', but even converts rarely achieved full legal equality, which continued to be imposed for centuries. The law called indigenous to all those who existed outside the standard of civilization expected of citizens, which were the non-white populations of Angola, Mozambique, Guinea and Timor. Macau will always have occupied a “privileged position” in the context of this empire. Specifically, how? In terms of citizenship, Macau has never been subject to the Indigenous Statute, which was in force in Angola, Mozambique, Guinea and Timor. This exclusion was not accidental. The Indigenous Statute applied to populations considered 'uncivilized' according to European racial and cultural criteria, being, in practical terms, essentially black populations from continental Africa and Timor. In Macau, the Chinese population, often called ‘Macau Chins’, although not European, were treated differently. There were laws that regulated the rights and customs of the Macanese population, with a complete law coming into force in 1909 and only abolished in 1949, for example. The Portuguese presence in Macau has always been accompanied by several other factors, such as British influence through contact with Hong Kong, the progressive political presence of Beijing, Portuguese political instability and the questioning of the existence of the Portuguese empire itself internationally. This meant that Portugal was unable to impose in Macau a sovereignty as powerful as that imposed in Africa and Timor. Were there cases of discrimination against the Chinese and Macanese communities before the 20th century? Discrimination existed, although of a different nature than that imposed in Africa. We can even see in literature, in the works of Senna Fernandes, for example, how the existence of walls, sides and parts of Macau, sometimes even ideological, for different populations, from Chinese villages to Christian cities. The same division occurred in the world of rights, only in an indirect way, and not through the direct imposition of indigeneity and the status of second-class national. Segregation and difference occurred socially, with difficulty accessing certain careers, the lack of invitations to birthdays because they were not ‘white’. This discrimination did not take the systematic legal form of indigeneity, as stated. The Macanese occupied an intermediate position, often functioning as intermediaries between the Portuguese and Chinese. Their ‘Portugueseness’ was recognized in an ambiguous way: they were Portuguese, but of a different type. We can mention that skin color was decisive in not placing Macau under the Indigenous Statute. Yes, skin color was absolutely decisive. The Indigenous Statute was applied in Angola, Mozambique, Guinea and Timor, territories with populations that are mostly black or ‘non-white’ in the colonial sense. Portuguese law even created the term 'oceanic race' to identify Timorese during the imposition of indigenato so that they could bring this population racially closer to African populations. Macau, Portuguese India, Cape Verde, and, to a certain extent, São Tomé and Príncipe, were excluded from this classification. The official criteria established 'uses and customs' and 'civilization' as the parameters to identify these people, but in reality these categories only functioned as a substitute for race: they were race, but by another name. The populations of Portuguese India and Macau, although not European, have always been spared the application of openly racist laws, despite local practices and policies imposing, most often indirectly, restrictions on the full citizenship of these populations, as I have described. Taking into account the Indigenous Statute, what evolution can you trace in terms of the concept of Portuguese citizenship? The Indigenous Statute, consolidated in the early 1930s, represented the maximum legal codification of racial exclusion. Indigenato was a legal form of racial segregation that created two categories of being Portuguese, namely being a Portuguese citizen (white and assimilated) and being indigenous Portuguese (the majority black). The indigenous people were legally Portuguese, but they were not citizens; they did not live with access to rights, but to restrictions, they lived, as I call it in the book, in a status of ‘negatory nationality’. Indigenous people could not vote, could not move freely, did not have the right to lawyers, were subject to forced labor, paid special taxes based on race, and could not attend the same schools or hospitals as whites. The evolution of the concept of Portuguese citizenship in this context is paradoxical: formally, everyone was ‘Portuguese’, but materially, citizenship was reserved for those who demonstrated ‘civilization’ through skin color or by proving themselves to be sufficiently assimilated despite being black. Assimilation was the only legal path to leaving indigeneity, but it required proving mastery of the Portuguese language, abandonment of African ‘uses and customs’, stable employment, ‘good moral conduct’, and military service. Very few could. What are the most flagrant cases of denial of rights that you can point to? One of the most flagrant is the system of forced labor, which functioned as a continuation of slavery under another name. Indigenous people were forced to work on plantations, mines and public works, often far from their families, in inhumane conditions. Another case is spatial and social segregation: separate hospitals for whites and indigenous people, segregated neighborhoods, different schools. In Guinea, indigenous people were forced to wear necklaces with metal plates. In Mozambique they were forced to pay radio taxes if they had a device. In Timor they were required to pay taxes if they moved from one local authority to another, or when they divorced according to local customs. The archives also show cases of indigenous people who, despite having moved to Lisbon, still continued to be treated as indigenous people. All thanks to a 1955 law that imposed indigenato status on any indigenous person in any part of the Portuguese empire – which was previously only applied in indigenato colonies. This was the case of the so-called ‘Lisbon Requests’, a group of assimilation applications that I found in the Lisbon Ultramarine Archive, where indigenous people who, having emigrated to the metropolis, tried to obtain recognition as citizens. The Indigenous Statute would be abolished years later, but the effects seem to have remained. I absolutely agree. And I say more: indigenato was a continuation of slavery itself, a reflection that is still felt today by so many communities touched by the Portuguese empire. The Statute was abolished in 1961, but decades of legal, educational and economic exclusion are not erased by decree. African populations have been systematically denied access to education, property, mobility and political participation for generations. This explains, to a certain extent, the difference between the different parts of the Portuguese empire, where Brazil, Angola, Macau and India occupy completely different spectrums in relation to levels of protection and access to rights. When the Statute was abolished, a context of restriction and necessity was already consolidated where the black majority survived without formal education and without access to basic rights. The post-colonial effects are equally profound: indigenato taught generations of Africans that their culture, language and way of life were inferior, and that to formally be someone, to be recognized as fully human before the law, they had to become white, they had to resemble, as much as possible, the colonizer. But even this formal assimilation rarely translated into real protection: legal recognition did not guarantee effective access to rights. Assimilation marks not only a historical period, but a way of seeing, feeling and surviving colonial history. This violence left marks that persist in Portuguese-speaking post-colonial societies and that can only be resolved when there is a process of acceptance, truth and reconstruction — something that the Portuguese State has not yet been able to do.

item.title: Exhibition | Eric Fok shows “Dreaming of the Occident” in Taiwan: “In Portugal, I see traces of my city”
item.description: The year began with a new project by Eric Fok, who despite living in Portugal did not leave Macau and the East. “Dreaming of the Occident” is on display at the Helios gallery, in Taipei, and can be seen until January 24th. To HM, the local artist reveals that he wants to artistically explore the universe of Vendas Novas bifana, through its connection to Macau pork chop How is the West represented in this exhibition? I've always been fascinated by the intersection between Eastern and Western cultures, and I've explored how Macau was a territory shaped by Western missionaries and navigators who brought new sciences and ideas to the East. Regarding a previous exhibition, and during the research process, I realized how rare it was for the Chinese to travel to Europe at the time of the Discoveries. I read with enthusiasm the reports of the few who did so. There are diaries that vividly recreate the dangerous sea voyages and what life was like in ancient European cities. This allowed me to project myself into their stories, bridging the gap between past and present, between East and East. These cultural differences are not just history to me, but have become a rich source of imagination for my new work. As an artist from Macau, how has the history of the territory, marked by exchange between East and West, shaped your way of thinking about this exhibition? It all started with mapping Macau for the “Paraíso” series [2014 exhibition], a project that was born out of my curiosity about the city's past in a context of rapid expansion of the tourism and gaming industries. Through this dialogue with local history, I began to truly understand the city. I went from focusing on the small details of urban life to having a macro perspective of the world, highlighting Macau's significant role in global history. This includes its status as a gateway to China during the Discoveries, its contribution to the beginning of globalization, or even being a space for the spread of Catholicism to the East. [We cannot forget] the profound influence of maritime culture. All of these themes constitute an extension of my exploration of the historical and unique experience of Macau. Can you describe in more detail the creative process for “Dreaming of the Occident”? In addition to maps of Macau, this exhibition also presents maps of Eurasia and several Asian colonies, where I explore themes such as navigation, trade and empire. My research also extends to experimenting with materials. In addition to using paper and wood, I incorporated unconventional supports, such as ostrich eggs. These objects function as canvases to narrate stories about endemic species and the history of migration, establishing a bridge between a biological and historical side. Does the exhibition intend to criticize the Western influence in Macau, reflect on it or simply observe it?
